EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

February 19, 2007
                                                       4000 WESTCHASE BOULEVARD, SUITE 530, RALEIGH, NC 27607
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                          Appendix A



Introduction
Cornell University, with the Town of Ithaca Planning Board as Lead Agency, is preparing a
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS). Its purpose is to
identify and evaluate the transportation-related impacts of hypothetical university population growth
scenarios on transportation systems and neighborhoods over the next decade. It will also identify
potential mitigation strategies for those impacts. This will result in a set of strategies intended to
improve transportation options for the entire Cornell commuting population and reduce adverse
transportation impacts on the community. The primary emphasis will be on identifying ways to
reduce the number of motor vehicle trips traveling through residential neighborhoods to and from
Cornell. It will identify ways of getting people, not vehicles, to campus, and will include
recommendations for transportation demand management, multi-modal transportation strategies
including pedestrian, bicycle, transit and parking, safety, access and circulation modifications, such as
traffic calming, zoning changes and other measures.
In April 2006, as part of the transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-
GEIS), Cornell University embarked on a travel survey of the entire campus community: faculty,
staff, undergraduates, and graduate and professional students.1 The survey served not only to
provide a baseline for current travel habits and patterns; it also attempted to gauge the community's
interests in and preferences for an array of transportation programs and options with the ultimate
goal of reducing single-occupancy vehicle trips to and from the Ithaca campus.
The summary below provides highlights of the survey data, focusing on key trends and results. It
frames the current travel situation and highlights areas which are central to the t-GEIS, and assesses
any potential mitigations that the t-GEIS may identify. The overall response rate for the survey was
quite high: in excess of 46 percent across all groups; employees had the highest response rate at over
56 percent; undergraduates were the lowest with an overall rate of about 36 percent; approximately
50 percent of all graduate and professional students responded to the survey.
Spatial Distribution of Cornell Population
Approximately one in three employee respondents report living outside Tompkins County while
more than half report living more than 5 miles from campus. Almost none of the employee
respondents live on the campus. Essentially all of the student respondents live within the county and
84 percent of graduate student respondents and 97 percent of undergraduate respondents live within
5 miles of the campus. Among graduate student respondents, some 16 percent report living on or
immediately adjacent to campus in university-affiliated housing, while nearly 60 percent of
undergraduate respondents report living there.
Typical travel times follow similar patterns as commute distance. Approximately half of employee
respondents report that it typically takes them less than 15 minutes to reach campus; the overall
average time is about 19 minutes, noticeably less than the national average of over 25 minutes.
About 57 percent of graduate student respondents typically take less than 15 minutes while 79
percent of undergraduate respondents report they can normally reach campus in that amount of
time.




1Surveys were sent to a random sample of 2,800 employees (1,400 faculty and 1,400 staff) and 1,400 of each
undergraduate class (5,600 total). In addition, surveys were sent to all 5,647 graduate and professional students.

driving alone to campus. Another
2.5 percent share a ride or are dropped off. Approximately 15 percent of undergraduate respondents
ride TCAT to campus and just over 5 percent rely on private shuttles to reach campus; only 1.4
percent report biking. The vast majority living off-campus ­ nearly 71 percent ­ normally walk to
campus.
Overall, about 75 percent of all respondents vehicle commute trips on a typical day are made by
employees. The bulk of these trips are several miles in length with nearly a third of all employee
respondents driving 5 or more miles each way by themselves each day on their way to and from
campus.
Frequency and Time of Travel
While 95 percent of employee respondents make at least one trip to campus during the day (with 14
percent making multiple trips) just 14 percent come to campus after 7:00 p.m. Of those who make




t-GEIS Travel Survey                                                                 3                                                                 Executive Summary
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                        Appendix A



evening trips, most arrive between 7:00 p.m. and 8:00 p.m. and leave between 10:00 p.m. and 11:00
p.m.2
The characteristics of the student respondents are noticeably different, however. While nearly all
graduate student respondents (98 percent) make at least one trip, nearly 30 percent make two or
more trips to campus on a typical day. Nearly half of all graduate student respondents (49 percent)
return to campus one or more times during the evening. The timing of their trips is much more
spread out than employee respondents, though. Only 19 percent arrive during the a.m. traffic peak
hour (7:30-8:30 a.m.). The most common hour for arrival, however, is 8:30-9:30 a.m. when 35
percent travel to campus. Similarly, only 18 percent leave during the p.m. traffic peak hour (4:15-
5:15 p.m.). The most common hour for leaving campus is between 6:00 and 7:00 p.m. when 23
percent depart campus. Most who return do so between 7:00 and 8:00 p.m. and leave around 10:00
or 11:00 p.m., although a substantial number stay as late as 2:00 a.m.
Undergraduate student respondents' travel patterns are relatively similar to those of graduate student
respondents: 98 percent make at least one trip during the day and 57 percent make multiple trips; 61
percent report traveling to campus at least once during the evening. Less than 6 percent arrive
during the a.m. traffic peak hour (7:30-8:30 a.m.). Nearly 2 in 5 (39 percent) arrive between 9:15-
10:15 a.m. Just over one-fourth (28 percent) leave campus during the p.m. traffic peak hour (4:15-
5:15 p.m.). The majority returns to campus around 7:00 or 8:00 p.m. and nearly 40 percent stay until
after midnight.
There are noticeable mode shifts for evening travel when people drive to campus. Over 80 percent
of employee respondents drive alone and nearly 7 percent share a ride with equal amounts (just
under 5 percent) taking the bus and walking. Approximately 3 in 5 graduate student respondents
drive alone to campus in the evenings with about 11 percent reporting that they take the bus and
over 22 percent walking to campus. Similar shifts are noticeable for the undergraduate respondents
as well, with 35 percent driving alone to campus, 7 percent sharing a ride, and only 5 percent riding
the bus; approximately half report walking to campus.


Reasons for Driving to Campus
The survey included several questions to identify current impediments to using alternative modes to
driving alone and the improvements necessary to entice respondents to use those modes. Over half
of employee respondents cite the need to run errands on the way to or from campus for why they
drive; 37 percent have to run work-related errands on or off campus; and one third want to have a
vehicle available in case of an emergency.
The most common reason cited by graduate student respondents for driving is that they "already
own a car so it makes sense to use it": nearly half feel this way. Over 40 percent report needing to
make stops to or from campus while 30 percent report needing to make "work-related" trips that
require a car and 29 percent report needing to run personal errands during the day.




2 Employees were not asked about their time of arrival for this survey. Based on the 2005 "Tompkins County/Cornell
Employee Commuter Survey," however, approximately 50 percent of employees report arriving during the morning
traffic peak hour (7:30-8:30 a.m.) while 45 percent report leaving during the afternoon traffic peak (4:15-5:15 p.m.).

The primary improvement required
to get those employee respondents who currently drive alone to switch to the bus is simply access to
the bus (a stop close to their home).3 Second to that ­ and most frequently cited overall ­ is an
increase in the frequency of the service. The demand for an increase in frequency is representative of
the primary reasons cited for not taking the bus to work: the time it takes and the bus schedule not
meeting their needs.

Of the few undergraduate respondents who currently drive alone to campus, access to transit is the
most important improvement to get them to take the bus, with nearly half indicating this need.
Nearly equally important, though, are increased frequency, faster routes, improved information and
a lower cost than driving and parking on campus. For all undergraduate respondents, the primary
impediment to using the bus is cost, followed by schedule and travel time.


3 Based on the geocoding, this may also indicate a need for education: some 40 percent of all employees live within
walking distance in normal conditions (¼ mile) of a bus route. Similarly, nearly 40 percent of graduate student
respondents cite the need for a stop near their home, but over 90 percent of all graduate students live within walking
distance of a route.

important, though, are more convenient parking, reduced permits costs and startup subsidies.

Both graduate and undergraduate student respondents are most concerned with the existence of
paths to campus. Also important are pavement condition, reduced conflicts and covered bicycle
parking.
Walk
Key to increasing walk mode share is the opportunity to live closer: over 30 percent of those who
currently drive alone say they would walk if they lived closer to campus.5 Also important ­ and less
easy to change ­ is the need to carry a less heavy or cumbersome burden to campus; support

t-GEIS Travel Survey                                                                          7                                                                                                             Executive Summary
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                         Appendix A



Opinions on Other Options
As part of the survey, several additions or modifications to the TDM program were posed to the
respondents. They were also queried about future directions for growth of the campus. This section
summarizes those responses.
Just over 70 percent of graduate student respondents and two-thirds of undergraduate respondents
feel that new students should be granted a free bus pass, although there is little agreement on how it
should be funded: whether from increased tuition and fees, parking prices, or general funds. The
third of the undergraduate respondents who did not think that new students should receive free
passes could be symptomatic of the bitterness that many of the upperclassmen respondents feel at
their ineligibility for the free passes (as was thoroughly expressed in the free response section of the
survey). Employee respondents feel that new students should receive a free bus pass as well, and
that its cost should be paid for by an increase in tuition/fees for all students. All groups strongly
agree that new students should only be eligible for such a pass if they do not purchase a parking
permit.
Students were asked to identify what incentives would be necessary to give up (i.e. not renew) their
parking pass. For both undergraduate and graduate student respondents the most common response
(significantly so) was a free transit pass. For graduate student respondents, better transit service is
the second most important improvement with the offer of free or reduced rate daily parking permits
also important. Undergraduate respondents identified both incentives as well, although the access to
daily permits is more important than improved transit service. Just over 10 percent of graduate
student respondents and 6 percent of undergraduate respondents who sometimes drive to campus
indicated that they would not give up their permit under any circumstances.
If parking prices were to increase significantly (to approximately $1,000), nearly one-third of
emmployee respondents who currently have a permit say they would not purchase a permit, while
just over one-fourth say they would elect to buy a cheaper permit. Among graduate student
respondents, just over half say they would continue to purchase the permit at full price while the
remainder would abandon their permit. Just over 3 in 5 undergraduate respondents would abandon
their permit if faced with such an increase.
If the parking subsidy were to change, graduate student respondents favor a decrease for
undergrads; 45 percent favor an increase in their subsidy while 37 percent say to leave it alone; they
favor no change for employees, although if there were one, they would lean toward a decrease for
faculty and an increase for staff. Undergraduate respondents, on the other hand, feel that subsidies
should generally remain unchanged, although lean toward an increase for all groups except faculty.
Over two-thirds of employee respondents feel that the undergraduate parking subsidy should
decrease. For all other groups they feel that it should remain unchanged, though were it to change, it
should decrease for graduate students and increase for staff.
Just under half of employee respondents would favor some sort of permit restrictions limiting
parkers to one parking zone (essentially eliminating cross-parking or the tiered privileges). Support
was strongest among those who do not drive alone. A majority of graduate student respondents
would support such a policy.
There is general support across all student respondents for some level of restriction on
undergraduate students' access to parking, particularly for freshman. Two-thirds of undergraduate
student respondents (including over half of the freshman) and 88 percent of graduate student
respondents feel there should be some restriction on freshman parking (requiring that they live at


t-GEIS Travel Survey                                          8                     Executive Summary
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                          Appendix A



least a certain distance from campus to be eligible to purchase a permit) with 40 percent and 55
percent, respectively, supporting a total ban on freshman parking. This support drops off for
increasing class year, with only 35 percent of undergraduate respondents and 73 percent of graduate
student respondents supporting restrictions on parking for seniors. Over 90 percent of faculty
respondents believe there should be some restriction for first year students and nearly 80 percent
feel there should be a restriction for seniors. Only 44 percent support a restriction for graduate and
professional students and less than 18 percent support restrictions on their own parking availability.
More graduate respondents (35 percent) support some restriction for graduate student access to
parking than do undergraduate respondents (27 percent). Similar numbers support restrictions for
employee parking (25 percent and 27 percent, respectively).
Parking Ratio and Location
Just over one-third of employee respondents feel the university provides the right amount of
parking, while just over half feel there should be some increase in parking. Nearly 30 percent of
graduate student respondents feel there is enough parking on campus, while just over half feel there
should be more parking. Approximately 20 percent of undergraduate respondents feel parking levels
are about right while some two-thirds feel there should be an increase. Of all who favored an
increase (for all groups), most favored an increase of 10-15 percent over current levels.
For all groups, about half favor the incorporation of new parking spaces in new buildings where
feasible as the preferred location for new parking. Just over 40 percent favor constructing parking
garages on existing surface spaces. As to the location of new parking, employee and graduate student
respondents have nearly identical opinions, with approximately 55 percent favoring locations evenly
distributed on the periphery of campus with shuttle service to the center of campus and
approximately 27 percent favoring spaces at the center of campus. Undergraduate respondents as
well would prefer spaces distributed around the periphery of campus (46 percent), but almost as
many would prefer new spaces at the center of campus (40 percent). Additionally just over 20
percent of all groups feel that the university should work to close all non-visitor lots in the center of
campus.
Conclusions
Several conclusions can be drawn from the survey data:
    ·    Cornell and its employees continue to be national leaders in the use of alternative modes.
         Whereas, nationally, 75 percent of workers drive alone to work, only 55 percent of Cornell
         employees do. Similarly, less than 5 percent of workers nationwide use public transportation
         compared with 14 percent of Cornell employees. The use of alternative modes is even higher
         among Cornell graduate and undergraduate students.
    ·    Employees, though, have a larger impact on the Ithaca area transportation system than do
         graduate or undergraduate students: 75 percent of all Cornell commuting vehicle trips today
         are made by employees. Their proportion of the vehicle trips increases noticeably in the peak
         hours ­ when travel on the roadway system is highest ­ as they account for over 90 percent
         of all Cornell vehicle trips in the AM peak hour and about 85 percent in the PM peak hour.
    ·    There is generally a high level of interest in and potential for increase in usage of alternative
         modes: approximately 80 percent of all employee respondents who currently drive alone say
         they would consider using the bus; about 50 percent say they would consider carpooling;
         about one-third say they would consider using a vanpool; 40 percent say they would consider
         biking; and about 50 percent say they would consider walking.


t-GEIS Travel Survey                                          9                      Executive Summary
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                       Appendix A




    ·    There is an array of reasons why individuals feel the need to drive or why alternative modes
         do not meet their needs. While some of these can be addressed, others are more difficult or
         impossible to change. Thus it is critical that future TDM programs be comprehensive and
         provide an array of options to employees and students.




t-GEIS Travel Survey                                         10                   Executive Summary
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)




                                             Appendix B
                                             t-GEIS Public Input

                                 - Neighborhood Feedback from 2006/2007
                                   t-GEIS Public Open Houses

                                 - Comments from t-GEIS Disability Workshop

                                 - Comments Posted to t-GEIS Website

                                 - Other Correspondence
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                         Appendix B




    Public Input to the Draft t-GEIS

    The following information in Appendix B records public input provided during
    development of the draft t-GEIS. Most of the public input comments were provided during
    the t-GEIS public open houses, described below. Some comments also were posted to the t-
    GEIS website, or mailed directly to Cornell representatives or the t-GEIS consultants. While
    the goal of gathering public input (especially during the public open houses) was to gather
    information about neighborhood livability and transportation issues relative to Cornell
    commuters, all comments were recorded, even if they were not directly related to Cornell.
    Documents from all of these public forums were posted on the t-GEIS website.

    Most of the comments received during the t-GEIS public open houses are graphically
    represented according to neighborhood on the following maps. Verbatim comments from
    the open houses, comments from the Disability Advisory Council public forum, and
    comments received on the t-GEIS website follow the maps.

    Five public houses were held during development of the t-GEIS to gather information about
    livability and transportation issues in areas being examined for neighborhood livability in the
    t-GEIS. A sixth public forum was held to gather information about community-wide
    disability issues relative to transportation.

    The first open house, held in April 2006, was designed to specifically gather information
    about pedestrian and cycling issues, and to solicit ideas on how to increase bicycle and
    pedestrian commuting to Cornell. Two more open houses were held in May 2006 to gather
    more general information about neighborhood livability and transportation issues, and to
    solicit ideas about how to increase commuting to Cornell by alternative modes of
    transportation, such as transit, walking, or cycling. These two workshops presented the same
    material but were conducted in two different locations ­ Downtown Ithaca and East Hill
    Plaza ­ to increase convenience and chances for public participation. The Ithaca
    Neighborhoods Council (INC) hosted the downtown open house, and the University
    Neighborhoods Council (UNC) hosted the open house on East Hill. In September 2006 the
    City of Ithaca Disability Advisory Council hosted a public form for the t-GEIS consultants
    to gather information about disability-related transportation issues.

    Two more public open houses were held a year later in April 2007 to review public
    comments received at the 2006 public open houses, present findings of the t-GEIS Travel
    Survey, get feedback on potential transportation impacts and mitigations, and identify more
    potential strategies for increasing the use of alternative modes of transportation and reducing
    single-occupancy vehicle use. As with the May 2006 open houses, these were also hosted
    separately by the INC and UNC downtown and on East Hill for the convenience of the
    participants.

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                                                       Appendix B




                                  Transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)
                                                                   For
                                       Ten-Year Transportation Impact Mitigation Strategies (TIMS)

                Matrix of Comments Received at t-GEIS Public Open Houses* in Spring 2006 and Spring 2007


*Includes all comments (written or oral) recorded by workshop proctors or attendees at the
Bike/Pedestrian Workshop (4/26/06), INC Neighborhood Workshop (5/1/06) and UNC Workshop (5/3/06)

                                        COMMENT                                                Municipality         Neighborhood


A        Comments about New/Improved Pedestrian Access:
     1      Install curb ramps on the sidewalk crossing the driveways into                City of Ithaca            Belle Sherman
            Maplewood Park from Mitchell Street.
     2      Complete sidewalk connection along Cornell Street to State Street             City of Ithaca            Belle Sherman

     3      Install sidewalk on East side of Cornell Street                             City of Ithaca              Belle Sherman
     4      Install sidewalk on Valley Road near Belle Sherman school                   City of Ithaca              Belle Sherman
     5      There are sidewalk gaps along Mitchell Street                               City of Ithaca              Belle Sherman
     6      Maple/Dryden/Cornell/Ithaca is horrible intersection for pedestrians/bikes- City of Ithaca              Belle Sherman
            no pedestrian signal (lots of pedestrians/bikes)

     7      Need a sidewalk along Bryant Park on Ithaca Road                              City of Ithaca             Bryant Park
     8      Need a sidewalk on Oak Avenue                                                 City of Ithaca             Collegetown
     9      The sidewalk on Dryden Road between Maple Ave. and Collegetown is             City of Ithaca             Collegetown
            very narrow and the overgrown vegetation blocks the sidewalk in some
            locations.
    10      Opportunity to increase foot traffic/ revitalize area of Stewart Ave. which   City of Ithaca             Collegetown
            includes ABC Cafe
    11      Poor or missing sidewalks along Oak Ave                                       City of Ithaca             Collegetown
    12      Narrow sidewalk along Dryden Road in between Elmwood and Delaware             City of Ithaca             Collegetown
            avenue
    13      Pedestrian/Vehicle conflicts especially on weekends (at Dryden Rd &           City of Ithaca             Collegetown
            College Ave)
    14      Dangerous pedestrian crossing at Renwick Hts Rd and Lake St                   Town of Ithaca(?)         Cornell Heights
    15      The pedestrian light at the top of the stairs between Dryden Road and         Cornell University       Cornell University
            the Crescent Lot should be a lot brighter. The lights in the middle and at
            the bottom of the stairs are OK, but the light at the top is so dim that it
            feels unsafe even starting down the stairs.

    16      Need a sidewalk on Pleasant Grove Road between Hasbrouck                      Town of Ithaca             Forest Home
            Apartments and Forest Home

            to plantations

            cyclists use Forest Home Road (300 block) ­ no sidewalks. Recent

B        Comments about New / Improved Pedestrian Crosswalks:
     1      Need a crosswalk across Ithaca Road to Bryant Park                         City of Ithaca             Bryant Park
     2      Need a crosswalk across Caldwell Road at Plantations Road                  Cornell University         Forest Home

            pedestrian trail behind Mann Library. Pedestrian crossing signs should
            be installed to make motorists aware of this crosswalk.
     4       Need a crosswalk at the intersection of Forest Home Drive and Warren      Town of Ithaca             Forest Home
            Road. Pedestrian crossing signs should be installed to make motorists
            aware of this crosswalk.
     5      Unsafe pedestrian crossing at Honness Lane and Pine Tree Road              Town of Ithaca          Honness Lane; Pine
            Intersection                                                                                           Tree Road
     6      Need pedestrian crosswalks in Varna. Mailboxes are on opposite side of     Town of Dryden                Varna
            road
     7      Marked pedestrian crossing on wide state routes like Route 13 to           City of Ithaca               Various
            Farmers Market, or across Route 96 from Overlook. Need to work with
            the state on this
     8      Create pedestrian islands in the middle of wide roads such as Route 13     City / Town of Ithaca        Various

     9      Students & bus takers cross here (Route 79 @ Army Reserve). Cars           City of Ithaca               West Hill
            don't slow down
    10      Continue sidewalk along Cayuga & Lake Streets to Stewart Park              City of Ithaca             Fall Creek
    11      Make safer crosswalk to Boynton Middle School                              Town of Ithaca           Cayuga Heights
    12      New signal planned at Dryden Rd./College Ave. intersection by City for     City of Ithaca            Collegetown
            2008 construction

            intersection

C        Comments about Pedestrian, Miscellaneous
     1      No uniformity in sidewalks ­ complicated issue
     2      Sidewalks not plowed. Otherwise beautiful walk
     3      Thanks to the Town for the path from Eastern Heights to Judd Falls         Town of Ithaca           Eastern Heights
            Road
     4      Sidewalks: need more and they should be maintained by municipality

     5      Add Pedestrian / Bike entranceways to campus, especially those that        Various                      Various
            wouldn't require lots of hill climbing
     6      Separate various transportation modes; i.e. walk along Cascadilla Creek
            is pleasant/maintain in winter
     7      Rebuilding walkway on Judd Falls Road is good example ­ heavily
            utilized (walkers/joggers)
     8      Raised X-walks don't work and become a maintenance problem
     9      I support speed tables/ calming (widespread support)
    10      Precautions should be taken to maintain easy access to sidewalk
            "tripper" buttons in the winter. Now snow generally gets piled at the base
            of the poles these "tripper" buttons are mounted on and they are really
            difficult to get to.
    11      Use "grass-pave" in lieu of concrete or asphalt for sidewalks in some
            places
    12      Heed pedestrian only phrase at crossings: Route 89/ Buffalo,               City of Ithaca           Downtown Ithaca
            Buffalo/Fulton, Buffalo Meadow
    13      Sidewalk on one side of Hector Street up to Vinegar Hill, existing, very   City of Ithaca               West Hill
            expensive to continue, may not be politically feasible under existing City
            Uniform Sidewalk Improvement, property owners pay for construction

E        Comments about Innovative Ideas for Improving Biking
     1       Construct stairs with bike ramps integrated into them on campus.              Various              Cornell University

     2       Construct a suspension bridge over Cascadilla Gorge between Oak               Various               Collegetown /
             Avenue and the Theory Center, to cut across campus for bikers and                                  Cornell University
             walkers who now have to ride through crowded Collegetown streets

     3       "Memorial" bike rack program on campus                                        Various              Cornell University
     4       Designated bike lanes from point A to point B on campus                       Various              Cornell University
     5       Policy change needed ­ On Campus- Dismount only when pedestrians              Various              Cornell University
             are present
     6       Incentives to use Bike on Bus program
     7       Enforce yearly bicycle registration ­ keeps record of active cycling
             community
     8       Offer bikes to rent, just for the school year
     9       There is no central location of information about available showering                              Cornell University
             facilities for people who commute to campus via bicycle

    10       Offer bike storage at commuter lots                                           Various             Various
    11       Bike lift on hills/assistance on hills
    12       A community-wide shared bike fleet. Paint all of the bikes in the fleet a
             bright color to identify them as part of the fleet.
    13       SUNY Cortland has a bike share program (Yellow Bikes)
    14       Consider bike lockers, bike cage, bike parks....Establish a bike park
             at/near Maple Ave
    15       "Buddy System" encouragement for new bike commuters
    16       "AAA" for Bikes ­ roadside assistance

F        Comments about Bicycle Education
     1      Bike route signs are needed particularly off-campus (e.g. Triphammer    Various                     Collegetown /
            Rd, Collegetown)                                                                                   Cornell Heights /
                                                                                                                   Others
     2      Bicycle signs needed on Rt. 366                                         Town of Ithaca / City of
                                                                                    Ithaca

            education information

            Wellness/IC Web-based incentives (check with Beth)
     6      Signage Re: Care around Cyclists
     7      Better/more bicycle education. Educate motorists on "shared roadway"
            concept. Educate motorists RE bicycling (rules of the road, share the
            road, courtesy, etc.).
     8      Education ­ Commuting, Repairs, etc.
     9      Places where bike lanes end need clarification to bicyclists and need
            more education for motorists
    10      Bicycle awareness and road condition for bicycles need improvement

     7      R-1 zoning: can't have more than 2 unrelated persons. Enforce R-1 so         City of Ithaca           Belle Sherman
            that faculty will want to live here. Because it's not enforced,
            neighborhood is becoming more student oriented. Faculty living here
            means they can walk to campus. Preserve single family neighborhoods
            of Belle Sherman and Bryant Park (to be stable and attractive to faculty
            and staff). Otherwise they'll move out, further away and drive to campus.

            city center ­ if preserved as single family residential - entire city is
            walkable for them

       Comments about Housing / Land Use Planning (cont.)
     4    Attractive affordable housing in city; people can live closer to work
          destination so they can walk or bike
     5    Educate public on: Affordable housing and models of workable &
          walkable cities
     6    Cornell needs to provide affordable housing as a buffer between the
          university and neighborhoods such as Belle Sherman. The City should
          pay closer attention to zoning to minimize multi-unit rentals encroaching
          on neighborhoods like Belle Sherman. These multi-unit rentals
          destabilize single family neighborhoods. Affordable housing provided by
          Cornell would help re-stabilize them.

     7      Subsidized housing, particularly for lower paid employees, such as
            service workers
     8      Successful transportation planning should include land use planning. To
            discourage far flung housing , large lots, etc

    t-GEIS Project
    Disability Advisory Council Workshop Comments
    Sept. 6, 2006

    Attendees:
    Larry Roberts, Chair, Disability Advisory Council
    Greg Gizewski, Vice Chair, Disability Advisory Council
    George Eberhardt
    Sherri Thurston, FLIC
    George DeMond
    Lauren Signer, Chief, Ithaca Police Department
    Charlie Dorsey ­ Youth Bureau
    Judy Willis ­ Gadabout
    Andrea Haenlin-Mott-Employment & Disability Institute, Cornell University
    Helen Steh ­ Customer Service Manager, Transportation & Mail Services, Cornell University
    Erin Sember-Northeast ADA & IT Center, Cornell University
    David McElrath
    Elizabeth Phelps
    Janie Karinin ­ (TCAT?)
    Citristen Bonacci
    Buzz Ortiz

    Gary Stewart ­ Associate Director, Community Relations
    Kathryn Wolf ­ Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects
    Annette Marchesseault ­ Trowbridge & Wolf Architects


    Comments

    ·    Need more expansion of rural bus routes

    ·    It's nice that the t-GEIS is doing neighborhood livability analysis and taking into
         consideration that City streets are used as access routes. People often drive into the City from
         out of town, park on residential streets, then walk to take bus up to Cornell.

    ·    Take into consideration through-traffic on the campus, where Cornell is not the destination
         but people drive through campus to get to a destination on one side or the other.

    ·    Cornell is it totally inaccessible for a manual wheelchair.

    ·    What about a fleet of inexpensive electric scooters to get around campus? They are illegal on
         public streets, but may be legal on private streets at Cornell.

    ·    Another idea is to have students volunteer to drive folks home after events.

    ·    There's a need for an accessible taxi in this community.

    ·    The $6 bus fare is difficult on a fixed income.

    ·    Label busses on the side, not just the front, so it's easy to locate them when they are all lined
         up at the library.


                                                           1 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                                 Appendix B




    t-GEIS Project
    Disability Advisory Council Workshop Comments
    Sept. 6, 2006



    ·    It would be nice to have buses without steps.

    ·    Shared bike lanes are needed on major streets in the city, such as State Street. Right now
         pedestrians have to dodge bicycles on sidewalks.

    ·    There's a need for bicycle education for students. It's illegal to ride on walks if you are over
         age 12 or if it's dangerous to ride in the street. The "dangerous" to ride in the street part is a
         little ambiguous.

    ·    Construction on the Cornell campus makes it very difficult to commute to and around
         campus. When there's lots of construction even detours have construction on them. It's very
         difficult to keep up with what's going on to be able to plan routes. Better dissemination of
         information would be helpful.

    ·    Routes around construction zones are supposed to be accessible and that doesn't always
         happen.

    ·    There probably is a bus that would work for me to get around campus, but I'm not sure how
         to find out about it. It took a year to even learn how to use the bus system on campus. Tell
         people how it is accessible & how to use it.

    ·    Some bus pull-offs (on campus) do not have curb ramps.

    ·    Accessible routes should be equitable as well as accessible. Sometimes accessible
         routes/entrances are not always equal to other routes; it takes more time to find the or to use
         them.

    ·    Transportation must be clear for people with visual disabilities. Right-on-red turns for cars
         can very dangerous for pedestrians, especially those with visual disabilities. We need
         education so drivers know pedestrians have the right to walk before a car has the right to turn
         right on red.

    ·    Snow and ice removal is a huge issue, especially at bus stops. The bus can't lower its lift in
         snow banks. It's also a problem getting off the bus into a snow bank.

    ·    Blind people can't tell which busses are lined up at the library.

    ·    Maintaining independence is really important for disabled people.

    ·    Many disabled people are deterred from using buses because of difficult waiting conditions,
         such as heat, cold, cigarette smoke, standing for long periods, etc.

    ·    If I were just commuting to and from campus I might use an alternate mode of transportation,
         like the bus, but I need to get around campus so I drive, because I may be able to get to my
         destination (ie., downhill) but cannot get back (ie, uphill) in my wheelchair.



                                                           2 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                                Appendix B




    t-GEIS Project
    Disability Advisory Council Workshop Comments
    Sept. 6, 2006



    ·    Look at the statistics of the aging population. There will be an increasing number of people
         who will have need for disability services.

    ·    Transportation services need to be affordable for people on a fixed income.

    ·    There needs to be more education on how to use the disability transportation system at
         Cornell.

    ·    It is difficult to get to events at Cornell, especially in the evening, because you often need to
         walk long distances from parking.

    ·    Lots of people in rural areas call Gadabout, not because they are disabled, but because they
         just live far out and don't have access to good transportation.

    ·    Cornell has the potential to grow so big so fast that it may outgrow its space. Can they slow
         down and let community infrastructure catch up?

    ·    Was Ithaca College potential growth considered?

    ·    City schools let out between 2:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. and the Youth Bureau releases vans at
         2:00 p.m. to pick up students. Many disabled students can't use the public transit system to
         get to after school programs. After-school time is also a sort of "peak traffic" time in Ithaca.
         How might after-school programs be affected by an increase in Cornell traffic during this
         time period?

    ·    One of the biggest issues is students not paying attention and crossing the street against
         traffic. It's much worse on campus than downtown. Education & enforcement are really
         important.

    ·    I am a TCAT advocate. We need more rural routes.

    ·    A $45 (monthly?) bus pass for people on fixed incomes is unreasonable, but if you need to
         the ride the bus 7 days a week you need to buy a pass.

    ·    There is a big need for wheelchair-accessible taxis in this area. The Finger Lakes
         Independence Council gets calls from Cornell students looking for ways to get around.

    ·    Ride-share, vanpooling, zip cars, etc. need to be universally accessible up front. Don't just
         designate one car for the disabled.

    ·    There needs to be a well thought out travel training program for people with a wide range of
         disabilities, including developmental disabilities. There also needs to be better
         communication about how to use the system and how to make the system universally
         accessible.




                                                           3 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                                   Appendix B




    t-GEIS Project
    Disability Advisory Council Workshop Comments
    Sept. 6, 2006

    ·    I'm very thankful for Gadabout, but I live outside it's current drop-off zone, so sometimes
         have to go 1.5 miles on the shoulder of the road in my electric wheelchair from the drop-off
         point to my home. It would be nice to improve the drop-off footprint. This reinforces the need
         for better rural transit service.

    ·    There needs to be better parking on campus for accessible vans, etc.

    ·    There needs to be education and/or regulation RE speeding bikes, especially those coming
         down State Street from Cornell.

    ·    For all the grousing we do, we do have a pretty good transportation system for people with
         disabilities.

    ·    Park & Ride would help with para-transit issues a lot. Some people can't access busses from
         where they live. It's not that they can't access the busses period; it's just that they can't get to
         the bus stops from where they live. For instance, Gadabout could pick people up from home
         and bring them to a central location where they could catch the bus. A Park & Ride could act
         as a "transfer location." If this happened Gadabout could possibly afford to expand the
         corridor length by aggregating several passenger pick-ups in one trip.

    ·    There's also a need for a Park & Ride in downtown Ithaca, not just out in Lansing or further
         out.

    ·    TCAT has a good phone system for passengers to call and ask how to use the system.

    ·    TCAT also has a new booklet (TCAT Ride Guide) which is available on the buses, around
         town, at Cornell Transportation Services, etc.

    Date: Mon, 12 Dec 2005 09:51:29 -0500 (EST)

    ---------------------------- Original Message
    ----------------------------
    Subject: t-GEIS Project
    From:    "Cynthia Brock" <cynthia.ny@earthlink.net>
    Date:    Mon, December 12, 2005 8:14 am
    To:      tgeis-mailbox@cornell.edu
              jkanter@town.ithaca.ny.us
              mcoles@cityofithaca.org
              timlo@cityofithaca.org
    -----------------------------------------------------------------------
    To: Cornell University (tgeis-mailbox@cornell.edu) Town of Ithaca
     (jkanter@town.ithaca.ny.us) ) City of Ithaca (mcoles@cityofithaca.org,
    timlo@cityofithaca.org) West Hill Civic Association
    (WestHillCivicAssociation@yahoogroups.com)
    11 December 2005

    Dear Sir and Madam:
    I am writing to comment on the Draft Scope of the upcoming t-GEIS
    Project, dated 15 November 2005. As specified in this document, the
    purpose of this environmental impact statement is to identify, examine
    and evaluate the impact of Cornell's off-campus students, faculty and
    staff transportation patterns on the community. One of the ultimate
    purposes to be to outline ways to reduce single-occupancy vehicles
    travelling to and from Cornell's campus.

    I would like to propose the following changes to the t-GEIS Project:
    Inclusion of West Hill as a stakeholder group Inclusion of the
    following streets and intersections to be evaluated:
    Hector Street/Mecklenberg Road (Rt 79)
    Intersection of Hector Street (Rt 79) and 13A Elm Street Extension
    Cliff Street (Rt 96)

    As I mentioned in the Town of Ithaca Planning Board meeting on 6
    December 2005, I urge the Town and Cornell to include West Hill as a
    residential neighborhood impacted by Cornell traffic both at current
    levels and as Cornell expands in the future, and as such should be
    invited to participate in this study.

    West Hill is significantly affected by Cornell traffic caused by
    off-campus students, faculty and staff for the following reasons:
    As real estate prices have risen and continue to rise in Cayuga
    Heights, Belle Sherman and Fall Creek, West Hill has become one of the
    few areas convenient to campus which offers affordable homes and rental
    units for graduate students, faculty and staff.

    Linderman Creek has become a popular alternative to on-campus family
    housing for many graduate students with family. An increasing number of
    young faculty with families have purchased homes in West Hill as it
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                 Appendix B




    offers both affordability and a suburban feel(namely yard space and
    distance between homes).
    With Cornell's expanding agricultural programs in addition to a new
    program in the science of wine making, commuter traffic through West
    Hill is increasing rapidly. West Hill is a residential area with little
    commercial zoning. Even the slightest rise in traffic volume
    significantly affects its residents who must deal with corresponding
    increases in noise, difficulty in exiting/entering driveways, and
    inability to walk safely to neighbors homes or safely cross the street.

    As identified by various city and town committees, West Hill is one of
    the few areas in Ithaca which contains undeveloped acreage. Indeed, as
    I witnessed at this last Town Planning Board meeting, 2 out of 3
    developments to be discussed are located on Mecklenburg Road. Both
    projects will create increased traffic volume on Hector Street, adding
    to the already high volume of traffic over-burdening this residential
    street.

    I would like to remind the City and Town of Ithaca as well as Cornell
    that significant portions of Hector Street and West Hill lack basic
    city services such as sidewalks, crosswalks, multi-purpose trails, bike
    lanes or even designated shoulders. As a Cornell affiliate, my family
    and many of my neighbors would embrace the opportunity to leave our
    cars at home and use other means to get to campus and town, but are
    prohibited from doing so because we cannot safely walk, ride our bikes
    or catch the bus.

    To attempt any of these, we must walk, ride or stand in the roadway, on
    busy and sometimes winding narrow streets where cars travel at an
    average of over 45 miles an hour. As an added deterrent, even if we
    could safely take TCAT, its frequency (or lack thereof during afternoon
    hours) and lack of an direct route to and from campus make utilizing
    this service prohibitive.

    The current speed and volume of cars entering Ithaca and Cornell
    through West Hill has been the topic of ongoing concern to our
    residents. Our residential neighborhoods have come to be considered by
    these commuters as a corridor to be driven through as quickly as
    possible with no regard to neighborhood speed limits, pedestrians,
    school bus stops or school zones.

    We as a community must do whatever is in our power to improve the
    safety and habitability of our neighborhood. Essential to this process
    is to not allow ourselves to be disregarded by our City and Town
    governments and Cornell University. I urge you to acknowledge Cornell's
    impact on West Hill. I sincerely hope Cornell and the Town will include
    our community in your study and allow us to participate in the t-GEIS
    Project by offering comments and possible alternatives and solutions.

    Sincerely,
    Cynthia Brock and Raymond Craib
    409 Campbell Avenue
    Ithaca, NY 14850
    607 280-0661
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                                 Appendix B




    -------- Original Message --------
    Subject:scope of transportation study
        Date:Thu, 27 Jul 2006 15:59:23 -0400
       From:Betsy Magré <bmagre@gmail.com>
          To:tgeis-mailbox@cornell.edu


    To whom it concerns: I read the February 7, 2006 Final Scope document and was
    concerned about the stated objective of this project from a neighborhood perspective.
    The first paragraph of the document, under the heading Introduction and Background,
    subheading Purpose of t-GEIS states that the "major objective of the t-GEIS is to
    develop ways to reduce the number of trips by motor vehicles traveling through
    residential neighborhoods to and from Cornell." I have lived for six years on East
    Buffalo Street hill, one of the major transportation corridors to Cornell from West
    Hill, South Hill and many other areas. I contend that reducing the number of vehicles,
    although a valuable goal, is the LEAST effective way to measure true impact on a
    neighborhood. I would rather have 18 Toyota Camrys drive up Buffalo Street hill than
    one city bus or campus delivery truck. Neighborhoods are affected most negatively and
    made unlivable by NOISE and UNSAFE DRIVING. If this study doesn't factor in the
    noise generated by large vehicles such as buses and make recommendations about
    mitigating speeding and bus noise, then I fear it will end up being an expensive but
    largely ineffective effort in terms of reducing the impact of traffic on neighborhoods.

    Please let me know if there is another forum in which I should air my concerns.
    Thank you,
    Betsy Magre
    --
    Betsy Magre
    413 E Buffalo Street
    Ithaca, NY 14850
    607-277-3142
    bmagre@gmail.com

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                 Appendix B




    -------- Original Message --------
    Subject:     Thinking Big
    Date:     Wed, 18 Apr 2007 13:40:15 -0400
    From:     Nathanael Nerode <neroden@fastmail.fm>
    To:     tgeis-mailbox@cornell.edu

    Looking at the current state of things, plus the projected growth, it
    seems that the demand for the core circulation through Cornell, as
    well as for the heaviest line-haul routes (TCAT 10 and 30) has gotten
    to the point where it might support a fixed transit link more
    efficiently than buses.

    In other words, Cornell should seriously consider the cost-benefit
    analysis of a tram/trolley/streetcar. A natural "line haul" route
    would be essentially route 30; a natural "circulator" route would be
    essentially route 10 or route 81.

    It's well known that rail infrastructure gets a higher share of
    'choice' users than bus infrastructure, and that it can carry more
    passengers per vehicle, and that it attracts slightly more willingness
    to interchange than bus-to-bus interchanges.
    In addition, and more importantly, it can be routed off-road into its
    own lane where possible, allowing it to bypass congestion chokepoints
     (provided the right of way exists and the town/village/city allows it)
    and therefore run faster and more consistently. This is particularly
    significant for routes like the North Triphammer Road - Pleasant Grove
    Road route, which suffers very nasty congestion in rush hour, but
    where the right of way clearly has room for a separate single
    streetcar lane with occasional passing tracks along most of its
    distance (though probably not for a separate bus lane, since those
    have to be wider). Off-road or separate-lane routing for a streetcar
    is also extremely plausible in North Campus, West Campus, East Campus,
    and Central Campus It may prove not to be cost-effective, but it's
    definitely worth considering, and it wasn't even considered as a
    possibility, which is really an omission.

    Even if no such thing is adopted, I had a few other thoughts. Given
    the congestion on the North Triphammer - Pleasant Grove route between
    Pyramid Mall and A Lot, it is probably worth seriously considering an
    official park-and-ride lot in the Pyramid Mall grounds for Cornell
    employees living in Lansing (a substantial and still-growing
    population).

    Bus routes are currently a rats nest, which tries to hit everywhere,
    but hits most places with low (and varying) frequency, at low speed,
    and in very unmemorable patterns.

    This may be the best that can be done for outlying area commuters, but
    it doesn't seem like the best option for the central Cornell or
    downtown Ithaca routes. Almost all of them are loops which use
    different streets to go one way and the other, and often not even
    neighboring streets, but two or three blocks away; while this makes
    sense under some circumstances, it also means that the bus routes and
    schedules will never become memorable or easy to understand. Surely
    something more, well, systematic would help!
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement                         Appendix B

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D




                                             Appendix D
                                          Resource Committee
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D




    Date


    Name
    Address
    Address

    RE: Invitation to Appoint Resource Committee Members for
         Ten-year Transportation Impact Mitigation Strategies (TIMS) and
         transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)


    Dear:

    As part of a pro-active initiative, Cornell University and the Town of Ithaca are jointly
    undertaking a transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS) which
    will result in the development of a Ten-year Transportation Impact Mitigation Strategies (TIMS).
    An increase in the population that travels to Cornell (primarily staff, faculty and graduate
    students) affects transportation in the community surrounding the campus. The t-GEIS will study
    that effect on the surrounding community, and outline ways to reduce adverse transportation
    impacts of potential Cornell growth. Potential growth will be derived from a range of
    hypothetical Cornell campus growth scenarios over the next decade.

    TIMS will not be written before the t-GEIS. Rather, TIMS will evolve in response to the data and
    the public feedback obtained from the t-GEIS process. The mitigations and alternatives sections
    of the t-GEIS, in particular, will inform and shape TIMS, which may include recommendations
    for transportation demand management improvements, multi-modal transportation strategies
    including pedestrian, bicycle, transit and parking, access and circulation modifications, and
    zoning changes.

    We recognize that to be successful in this endeavor we need to draw on local expertise. We are
    asking you to help us assemble a Resource Committee for this important transportation-focused
    project. The purpose of the Resource Committee is to provide technical assistance through the t-
    GEIS process towards the development of TIMS. To that end, the Resource Committee will be
    composed of individuals from potentially involved agencies who are able to contribute technical
    knowledge about transportation issues because of their training and position.

    Members of the Resource Committee will be expected to contribute technical input, share
    knowledge, information and resources, provide critiques to the planning team and contribute a
    range of professional opinions on transportation planning.

    Committee members should expect to review and comment on reading materials provided in
    advance of meetings, contribute to technical discussions, and occasionally provide a brief
    presentation related to their area of expertise. Regular attendance at meetings is expected.
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D




    Frequency of meetings is estimated to be once every six to eight weeks for the duration of the
    project, which is expected to take up to two years.

    Please provide us recommendations for Resource Committee members relevant to your
    jurisdiction using the attached draft list as a guide. Please consider appointing Committee
    members who are able to commit to attending meetings on a regular basis for the duration of the
    project. We would like to receive your recommendations no later than September 13, 2005. We
    expect the first Resource Committee meeting to occur during the last week of September, and we
    anticipate that the Committee will meet three or four times during the scoping phase of the t-
    GEIS, which should be completed by mid-December 2005. The Committee will continue to meet
    regularly during the completion of the t-GEIS.

    Thank you in advance for helping to make this transportation-focused project successful for the
    entire community.


    Sincerely,




    Cathy Valentino, Supervisor                                          Bill Wendt, Director
    Town of Ithaca                                                       Transportation Services
                                                                         Cornell University

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                          Appendix D




                        Transporation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)



                                 Resource Committee Charge
                                              Prepared by t-GEIS Project Team
                                                    September 27, 2005



    The Charge For Members of This Resource Committee Shall Be: to provide technical
    assistance and guidance to the Town of Ithaca and Cornell University project team in the
    development of the transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS),
    AND to serve as a communications and feedback link between the t-GEIS project team and the
    Committee members' respective municipality or agency.

    Technical assistance may include:
       · Contribute professional knowledge, information and resources
       · Provide feedback to the project team regarding methodologies, information inputs, and
           proposed mitigations

    Resource Committee members also will serve as an integral link between their respective
    municipality or agency and the t-GEIS project team. Resource Committee members are expected
    to:
        · Update professional colleagues, agency representatives and/or respective municipal
           government leaders about the t-GEIS
        · Convey input from respective municipal or agency administrations to the t-GEIS project
           team
