transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                              Appendix D



                                          Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                         Resource Committee Meeting #11
                                                Meeting Minutes

                                           Meeting Date: June 27, 2007
                                      Date Minute Prepared: April 11, 2008

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: Bill Gray, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort,
                        Cornell University: Shirley Egan, David Lieb, Will Palmquist, Bill Wendt
                        Department of Transportation: Sean Murphy
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                        TCAT: Nicole Tedesco
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Cathy Valentino
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf

    1. The committee approved minutes from the 04/27/07 meeting.
    2. Committee members reported on current transportation-related projects in the county. Sean
       Murphy said that DOT officials had a very good meeting with t-GEIS representatives in early
       June to discuss potential mitigations in the t-GEIS that may involve DOT. He said there may
       be potential DOT funding for vanpool. Bill Wendt added that the regional director at DOT
       also is very interested in park-and-ride lots, and indicated that there might be potential
       funding for lots located near state routes. Nicole Tedesco noted that there is a line item in the
       TCAT budget for a comprehensive route study. David Lieb said that Ithaca Carshare, Inc. is
       very close to launch. He said the group is now negotiating with a national provider. Bill Gray
       reported that the City of Ithaca is discussing with DOT the possibility of DOT conveying
       jurisdiction over Green and Seneca Streets to the City in exchange for the City conveying
       jurisdiction over part of NYS Rt. 13 to DOT.
    3. Kathryn Wolf presented an overview of some of the potential mitigation strategies being
       developed for the t-GEIS. These included mitigation strategies related to land use and
       transportation, cycling and pedestrian network improvements, transit, Cornell's TDM
       program, park and ride, and vanpools and carsharing. She concluded that the t-GEIS analysis
       has shown that there is significant potential to move Cornell commuters out of SOVs and into
       alternative modes of transportation if incentive programs and improvements are put in place.
       She said the analysis also shows that impacts of most of the hypothetical Cornell population
       growth can be mitigated by moving Cornell commuters to alternative modes of transportation
       through TDM programs.
         Bill Wendt said that in the fall all Cornell first-year students will be provided a no-fee bus
         pass for their first year at the university, and a reduced-fee pass for their remaining time at
         Cornell. Additionally, all undergraduate and graduate students will be provided no-fee
         evening and weekend passes. Kathryn Wolf noted that the no-fee evening and weekend
         passes, as well as the TCAT transit route service study were ideas that surfaced during the
         development of the t-GEIS and are being put into motion now rather than waiting until the t-
         GEIS is complete.
         Nat Grier presented estimated increases in Cornell TDM participants for each hypothetical
         growth scenario. He noted that if these TDM participation rates were realized they could


                                                           1 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         mitigate all of the impacts of hypothetical new Cornell population growth in Scenarios 2 and
         3 and about two-thirds of the impacts in Scenario 4. The remainder of the Scenario 4
         mitigations likely would need to be achieved through roadway improvements. Ed Marx asked
         whether he was correct in his interpretation that as population grows at the university, Cornell
         will "ratchet" up its efforts to increase TDM participation, rather than instituting mitigations
         regardless of population growth. Bill Wendt said that generally was correct, although he
         noted that some mitigation strategies will need to be put in place now in anticipation of future
         population growth.
    4. Herb Engman said he appreciated the potential mitigation strategies related to land use and
       transportation, although he said he felt the language that Cornell will "advocate" for these
       strategies is too soft. He said he would prefer to see stronger language, such as Cornell will
       "commit" to these strategies. Thys Van Cort and Jonathan Kanter said they agreed. Bill
       Wendt noted that Cornell does necessarily feel it should lead the housing issue, but rather
       work with the appropriate municipalities.
    5. Fernando de Aragón noted that there may be an opportunity for Cornell to share its
       experience with TDM programs with other employers in the area, to help them establish their
       own TDM programs. Bill Wendt said he was supportive of that concept.


    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           2 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                           Appendix D



                                          Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                         Resource Committee Meeting #10
                                                Meeting Minutes

                                          Meeting Date: April 26, 2007
                                      Date Minutes Prepared: June 15, 2007

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: Tim Logue
                        Cornell University: Shirley Egan, Bill Wendt
                        Department of Transportation: Sean Murphy
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Kathryn Wolf

    1. The committee approved minutes from the 03/28/07 meeting.
    2. Nat Grier distributed a document titled "Intersection Analysis Summary". All sixty-six
       intersections included in the analysis are summarized. The attached tables identifying the
       following were reviewed: intersections with poor LOS today (poor LOS is defined as LOS
       D); additional intersections expected to have a poor LOS in 2016 without Cornell population
       growth, but with background traffic growth; and additional intersections expected to have a
       poor LOS in 2016 if population growth impacts from Scenario #4 are unmitigated. It was
       generally agreed that there were no big surprises in the intersections identified as either
       already having a poor LOS or in those expected to in the future. Improvements are already
       planned for some of these intersections. It was also generally agreed that even if there was no
       Cornell population growth, it would be desirable to improve many of the intersections listed
       for the purposes of safety, and the pedestrian and bicycle improvements that would be
       incorporated. Tim Logue cautioned that we shouldn't emphasize safety as a reason for the
       improvements because we have not technically conducted a safety analysis. Ed Marx stated
       that the CMP proposal will make some pedestrian routes more important.
    3. J. Kanter suggested that we should start thinking about TIMS in terms of coordinating with
       the CMP. He would like to see the TIMS identify big ideas of the CMP and figure out how
       we will address them. B. Wendt said the CMP won't be done in time to incorporate in TIMS.
       However, the 5-year update of the TIMS can address this.
    4. D. Kwasnowski asked if cost estimates will be included. Dan thought it would be good to see
       how much all the intersections would cost if it was federally funded, how much it would cost
       if it were done now, and how much it would cost if it were done in the future.
    5. K. Wolf provided an overview of the Public Open Houses and explained how the public
       comments were being recorded. She explained that the public comments were reviewed, and
       where the consultant team agreed with the recommendation, it was included on the diagram
       titled "Potential Transportation Improvements and Neighborhood Concepts". Ed Marx
       expressed concern that the county was not consulted regarding proposals on county roads. K.
       Wolf agreed to schedule a meeting with the county to review proposals on county roads and
       also to meet with NYSDOT to review proposals on state roads.
    6. Ed Marx stated that he is concerned about what everything is going to cost and how it is
       going to get done. G. Alexiou reminded the group that we are identifying problems whether



                                                           1 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                            Appendix D



         or not they are created by Cornell and we are identifying solutions that will benefit the
         community and that the intention was that all bodies would work together to find solutions. If
         Cornell was truly interested in the minimum investment, the intersection analysis shows that
         they could fix a few intersections and be done with it. B. Wendt stated that he wants to
         emphasize TDM programs and be out in front of the growth. J. Kanter stated that many of the
         issues brought up by neighborhood residents regarding corridors and intersections are not
         Cornell's responsibility. Ed Marx reminded the group that a community transportation plan is
         not the same as the t-GEIS.


    Prepared by,
    Kathryn Wolf
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           2 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #9
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                          Meeting Date: March 28, 2007
                                      Date Minutes Prepared: April 23, 2007

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: Tim Logue
                        Cornell University: Mina Amundsen, Andrew Eastlick, Shirley Egan, Bill
                        Wendt
                        Department of Transportation: Sean Murphy
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                        TCAT: Nicole Tedesco
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf

    1. The committee approved minutes from the 02/27/07 meeting. Herb Engman said that while
       he did not attend that meeting he was interested to read the discussion about the relationship
       between housing and transportation in the minutes. He said he hoped housing would be
       included as a mitigation measure in the t-GEIS. Kathryn Wolf noted that the t-GEIS will
       include a section regarding the relationship between land use and transportation, which will
       include information about housing.
    2. Committee members reported on current transportation-related projects in the county. Ed
       Marx said the Hanshaw Road reconstruction project is still moving forward and he hopes
       construction will begin in spring 2008. Jonathan Kanter said the Town Transportation
       Committee has received a draft of the Forest Home Traffic Calming Plan and is currently
       reviewing it. He said the Transportation Committee also has approved the Town
       Transportation Plan and it now will go to the Town Board for final approval, hopefully in
       May. Fernando de Aragón said a public meeting RE the TIP proposals will be held on April 9
       as part of the 30-day comment period.
         The t-GEIS consultants presented preliminary mitigation strategies for the t-GEIS and TIMS.
         Kathryn Wolf presented mitigation strategies targeted toward enhancing bicycle and
         pedestrian facilities and enhancing a bike culture in the community. She said while the focus
         would be on encouraging more people to cycle to Cornell, the benefits would be community-
         wide not exclusive to Cornell. Fernando de Aragón said he supports enhancing bike and
         pedestrian amenities and he hopes this mitigation strategy will receive support from all levels
         of the Cornell administration since these groups rarely are given priority over vehicles. Herb
         Engman recommended that education for drivers be included in the "bike culture" campaign.
         Ed Marx cautioned that the t-GEIS should not rely too much on mitigation measures that
         others are responsible for. He said improving county roads to accommodate cyclists includes
         many elements such as culvertizing drainage ditches in order to widen road shoulders. The
         county has estimated it could cost around $15 million to make such necessary improvements
         to safely accommodate cyclists on its roads, and at this time that money is not available.
         George Alexiou said that while the money may not currently be available, many of these
         mitigation measures should still be included in the plan. Jonathan Kanter noted that there are


                                                           1 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         certain roads that currently are in poor condition and require reconstruction, so bike facility
         improvements could be included in the road reconstruction projects. Fernando recommended
         establishing priorities and doing some feasibility analysis for these priorities.
         Nat Grier said the t-GEIS consultants have met with TCAT officials and the t-GEIS will
         recommend that TCAT do a comprehensive, community-wide transit service study. George
         Alexiou said such a study would help determine what transit means for the community as a
         whole and help determine what the community would like to see as improvements in the
         future. Ed Marx cautioned against making TCAT too Cornell-centric. He said he is concerned
         that could leave a gap in servicing rural areas. Bill Wendt pointed out that the current fixed
         route way TCAT is serving rural areas may not be the best way. Other strategies to better
         serve rural areas may be identified in the transit service study. Nicole Tedesco agreed that
         TCAT may want to look at other ways to address rural service.
         Nat Grier said Park and Ride lots are very important mitigation measures. He said the Park
         and Ride survey conducted in April 2006 helped determine five primary locations for lots
         near employment centers in the community. He said Cornell can assist in developing the Park
         and Ride system by making land available in some locations.
         Nat Grier provided an overview of TDM mitigation measures that Cornell is recommending.
         George Alexiou pointed out that Cornell already has a very good TDM program, but the t-
         GEIS analysis indicates that there is room to improve them. Tim Logue also noted that people
         should be encouraged to make decisions about where they live that minimize their
         transportation impacts, such as finding housing on a bus line.
         Nat Grier also provided an overview of intersection LOS analysis and possible intersection
         improvements. Kathryn Wolf noted that the potential intersection improvements are not
         necessarily being recommended at this point. Rather, the idea is to avoid impacts through
         TDM programs. Bill Wendt said that intersection improvements could be built into
         appropriate municipal work plans, and done as roads are reconstructed. Fernando de Aragón
         and Ed Marx recommended that the t-GEIS consultants provide this LOS analysis to
         Resource Committee members for further review.
    3. Herb Engman encouraged including flex hours as a mitigation in the t-GEIS. He pointed out
       that this would allow people to arrive at and leave work at staggered times, rather than during
       peak hours.


    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           2 of 2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                    Appendix D


                                  Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                 Resource Committee Meeting #8
                                        Meeting Minutes

                                Meeting Date: February 22, 2007
                              Date Minutes Prepared: March 7, 2007

 Attendees:       City of Ithaca: Tim Logue
                  Cornell University: Bill Wendt, Shirley Egan, Andrew Eastlick
                  Department of Transportation: Sean Murphy
                  ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                  Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                  TCAT: Nicole Tedesco
                  Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                  Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                  Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Jonathan Kanter
                  Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                  Wolf

 1. Susan Brock requested that the first sentence of the second paragraph under item 5 in the
    minutes from the 1/11/07 minutes be revised to read: "Susan Brock said she is not convinced
    that the sole focus should be on faculty/staff..." The Resource Committee agreed to accept
    the minutes from the 1/11/07 meeting with that revision.
 2. Committee members were asked to report on current transportation projects in their
    jurisdictions that are relevant to the t-GEIS. Dan Kwasnowski said the Town of Dryden
    currently is working to develop a multi-use trail that would extend from the East Ithaca
    Recreation Way to the Village of Freeville. He also noted that there is a need for Park & Ride
    facilities that would intercept commuters from Cortland who are driving through Dryden.
     Tim Logue said the City's TIP requests for reconstructing University Avenue and the upper
     portion of East State Street were not funded.
     Sean Murphy said Rt. 13/38 in Dryden will be resurfaced this summer.
     Jonathan Kanter said the final draft of the Town Transportation Plan will be forwarded to the
     Town's Transportation Committee tomorrow (2/23) and it hopefully will be adopted by April.
     He also said the Town and the ITCTC are meeting with Cornell about the North Campus
     Gateway.
     Ed Marx said the County's TIP requests for reconstructing the Pine Tree Road and Ellis          Deleted: studying
     Hollow Road corridors were not funded. He noted that the County currently is conducting a
     study of the Rt. 13/366 corridor with regard to nodal development. He said the County would
     like to also conduct a similar study on NYS Rt. 96.
     Andrew Eastlick said the ITCTC Park & Ride Committee will be meeting within the next few
     weeks to determine how best to use the Park & Ride survey data.
 3. George Alexiou provided a presentation about the traffic impact analysis that has been
    conducted for the t-GEIS and an overview of preliminary mitigation strategies. He pointed
    out that there currently are about 10 intersections and two corridors below level of service
    (LOS) C in the study area (existing condition). Two more intersections and two more
    corridors drop below LOS C with background growth. Two more corridors and another
    intersection drop below LOS C in the Cornell medium-growth scenario and the high-growth



                                                1 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                   Appendix D


     scenario causes one more intersection and one more corridor to drop below LOS C.
     Obviously, background growth and the various Cornell growth scenarios continue to diminish
     the LOS levels at intersections that currently are near or below LOS C.
     He said the bottom-line message is that the analysis shows that there are existing problems
     today and they get somewhat worse with background growth and Cornell growth scenarios,
     but the Cornell growth scenarios do not have an overwhelming impact.
     He said now that the traffic analysis has been completed the t-GEIS team is using data from
     the Travel Survey to develop proposals for ways to reduce single-occupancy vehicle use, thus
     mitigating traffic impacts projected in the Cornell growth scenarios. He said the preliminary
     mitigation measures are focusing on: 1) Transportation Demand Management (TDM), which
     are policies and programs that encourage commuters to use alternatives to SOV's; 2) physical
     improvements to facilities and services for non-motorists, such as pedestrians, bikers and
     transit users, and 3) physical improvements to roads and intersections where necessary and
     acceptable to the community, particularly to enhance safety and livability. He said Cornell's
     goal in the t-GEIS is to identify a wide range of options for commuters. The Travel Survey
     data confirmed that there is the potential to increase Cornell commuters' use of alternatives to
     SOV commuting. However, he pointed out, while the t-GEIS will identify many potential
     improvements, community-wide support will be required to realize many of those
     improvements, since many of them are beyond Cornell's jurisdiction. He noted that there
     needs to be a holistic system. As an instance, Park & Ride will not be successful if designated
     lots are provided but bus service is not reliable.
 4. Dan Kwasnowski asked whether there was any way to measure how many people used to use
    certain alternative modes of transportation, such as riding the bus, but stopped doing so for
    some reason or another. Bill Wendt said it is his professional opinion that many people stop
    riding the bus, for instance, because of childcare or other family issues, but they tend to return
    when those issues are not longer relevant. George Alexiou pointed out that the Travel Survey
    now provides a baseline of how the Cornell community commutes to campus, so changes can
    be tracked accurately every few year.
 5. Fernando de Aragón asked whether options for revised Cornell parking policies in the t-GEIS
    will include "pay as you go" options. George Alexiou said that option will be considered.
    Fernando pointed out that the appendix to the NESTS study contains some information about
    this option. He also recommended that physical improvements be recommended for roads and
    the overall biking network so bikers will feel safer.
 6. Susan Brock asked whether the "Trip Planner" on the TCAT web site was used in the
    transportation analysis, because she has noticed that it does not provide accurate information.
    Nat Grier said his firm noticed those inaccuracies so did not rely on the "Trip Planner." Susan
    also recommended that in future presentations the term "pedestrian network" be used instead
    of "sidewalk" network.
 7. Ed Marx said he feels that housing needs to be on the t-GEIS list of mitigations. Fernando de
    Aragón pointed out that there is a section in the t-GEIS that will address "Transportation and
    Land Use" and he hopes it will include recommendations for increasing residential density in
    certain areas. Ed said Cornell could recommend areas appropriate for dense residential
    development on its own land. Jonathan Kanter noted that there is an opportunity for the
    Cornell Master Plan (CMP) and the t-GEIS to identify land use opportunities that are
    mutually beneficial for the community and for the university. Tim Logue said Seneca Place is
    a good example of this. Jonathan also noted that Cornell could provide an incentive program,
    such as mortgage assistance, to encourage employees to purchase housing in targeted areas.



                                                2 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                 Appendix D


     Bill Wendt said the t-GEIS will not have specific recommendations with regard to land use or
     where to locate housing. He said the CMP is taking the lead on these issues. The t-GEIS role
     is to provide recommendations about the transportation components of specific CMP
     proposals, as they relate to commuting to campus. He also noted that housing generally is a
     community-wide issue and there are existing initiatives in the community that are beginning
     to address the issue. Jonathan Kanter said he sees an opportunity for the t-GEIS to provide
     recommendations to the CMP about the need for housing close to the university. He said if
     the t-GEIS and the CMP are viewed as two entirely separate entities they will not be
     particularly useful.
     Ed Marx said the Tompkins County Council of Governments is working to develop a strategy
     document that will, in part, encourage major employers to provide incentives for employees
     to purchase housing in targeted areas, and that nodal development will be encouraged. He
     pointed out that nodal, or densified, residential development provides a critical mass of
     people to make transit successful. He asked what type of future housing distribution the t-
     GEIS transportation analysis assumed. Bill Wendt said the analysis assumed that housing
     patterns would continue as they exist today, since that would be the worst case scenario. Ed
     said he feels strongly that even though the t-GEIS is not charged with making housing
     recommendations, it should include information about how land use and housing location
     directly influence transportation choices.
     Dan Kwasnowski noted that while it is easy to lay blame on Cornell for many issues, he
     agrees that there should be a County-wide initiative with regard to the housing issue, since it
     is so complicated and crosses so many boundaries. Ed Marx said he feels Cornell needs to
     provide support for such an initiative, even though the municipalities would be responsible
     for implementing it.
 8. The meeting adjourned at 3:30 pm. The next Resource Committee meeting will be March 28
    from 1:30-3:30 at the Borg Warner Room of the Tompkins County Public Library downtown.

 Prepared by,
 Annette R. Marchesseault
 Trowbridge & Wolf

 cc: Resource Committee members

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                              Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #7
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                         Meeting Date: January 11, 2007
                                    Date Minutes Prepared: January 15, 2007

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Bill Gray, Tim Logue
                        Cornell University: Bill Wendt, Shirley Egan, Mina Amundsen, Andrew
                        Eastlick
                        Department of Transportation: Sean Murphy
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Cathy Valentino
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf

    1. The Resource Committee voted to accept the minutes from the last meeting held on 03/27/06.
    2. Committee members were asked to introduce themselves since some new member have
       joined the Committee. Sean Murphy has replaced Bill Egloff as the DOT representative, and
       Cornell University Planner Mina Amundsen has joined the Committee.
    3. Committee members were asked to provide a brief overview of transportation-related projects
       that are under way or proposed in their jurisdictions. Ed Marx said Tompkins County
       currently is conducting a corridor analysis of Rts. 13 and 366, with an emphasis on looking
       for opportunities for nodal development. He said the project currently is approximately 50
       percent complete. He said the County also currently is involved in reconstruction projects for
       Hanshaw Road, Coddington Road and Warren Road north of Rt. 13.
         Fernando de Aragón said the ITCTC currently is reviewing a number of TIP proposals from
         the City, the Town and the County. He said one proposal of note is for the DOT to study the
         Rt. 13/Rt. 34 intersection south of the City for safety and improved traffic operation. Ed
         Marx clarification via e-mail on 1/22/07: This is a proposed widening of Route 13 south of
         the City to its intersection with Rt 34 rather than improvements to that intersection.
         Sean Murphy added that he can provide a map indicating all TIP applications from
         jurisdictions in Tompkins County.
         Tim Logue said the City has submitted TIP applications to reconstruct University Avenue and
         East State Street from Mitchell Street east to the City line to improve traffic conditions and to
         add bike and pedestrian amenities. Bill Gray said another City TIP application is for
         continuation of upgrading traffic signals in the City so they "talk" to each other and to the
         DOT signals.
         Ed Marx said the County has submitted TIP applications to study adding pedestrian and bike
         amenities along Pine Tree Road and Ellis Hollow Road.
         Jonathan Kanter reported that the Town Transportation Plan has been reviewed at two public
         hearings. The Town currently is in the process of making revisions and the plan should be
         submitted to the Town Board for final review within the next couple of months.




                                                           1 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         Mina Amundsen reported that Cornell is undertaking a Comprehensive Master Plan for
         physical development of the campus. She said the master plan is looking at the long term
         (25+ years) and is focused on development on campus, whereas the t-GEIS is looking at the
         short term (10 years) and is focused on transportation systems off campus.
         Dan Kwasnowski said that the Town of Dryden is rewriting the zoning for the hamlet of
         Varna. The new zoning will propose traffic calming and changes in land use.
    4. Kathryn Wolf provided a review of the overall t-GEIS process and reported on the public
       workshops held in Spring 2006. She said the t-GEIS consultants have been synthesizing
       written and verbal comments from the workshops into a graphic format which is helping to
       inform how comments should be addressed.
    5. Nat Grier and George Alexiou presented the results of the Travel Survey of Cornell faculty,
       staff and students conducted in Spring 2006. George said the survey response (46%) was one
       of the highest they have ever seen. Nat said survey questions were designed to provide an
       understanding of commuter attitudes and what changes would attract commuters to use
       alternatives to single-occupancy vehicles, and to determine the "market potential" for
       alternative modes of travel. He said the survey shows that more than 50 percent of faculty and
       staff (approximately 5,500) currently drive alone to/from work, while nearly 20 percent of
       graduate students and approximately five percent of undergraduates drive alone. He said
       since faculty/staff represent the largest group that is driving alone and the majority of them
       travel during peak commuting hours, they represent a significant opportunity for shifting into
       transportation demand management (TDM) programs. He said the survey indicates that the
       top three potential "markets" for TDM are: 1) increased bus ridership, 2) carpool programs,
       and 3) vanpool programs.
         Susan Brock said she is not convinced that the focus should be on faculty/staff since they
         indicated that they feel they need to drive because they use their cars for errands also,
         whereas graduate students indicated that if they owned a car it made sense to use it to
         commute. Bill Gray said that while the focus may be on faculty/staff, the t-GEIS should not
         overlook opportunities to get students out of their cars. Bill Wendt said focusing TDM
         strategies on faculty/staff likely would yield the "biggest bang for the buck."
         Nat said the best way to maximize the effect of TDM programs, such as the bus, is to focus
         on people who come and go once at each end of the day (ie, during the peak commuting
         hours), and these are primarily faculty/staff. He pointed out that approximately only 20
         percent of faculty/staff said no improvement could make them take the bus, which indicates
         that 80 percent may be willing to take the bus under the right conditions. Getting even half of
         that 80 percent to ride the bus instead of drive would still represent a significant number.
    6. Nat Grier said that another interesting survey result was that less than 10 percent of
       respondents said "close, affordable housing" would encourage them to walk more, while
       more than 30 percent said they would walk more often if they "live(d)" closer, indicating that
       affordability may not be the only factor in choosing where to live. Jonathan Kanter and Ed
       Marx cautioned against interpreting that this means affordable housing is not a significant
       issue, because other studies have indicated otherwise.
    7. Bill Wendt and Kathryn Wolf said Cornell is developing an executive summary of the Travel
       Survey which will be distributed to the Resource Committee when it is complete.
    8. Tim Logue asked if results of the 2005 Park & Ride survey would be used in conjunction
       with the results of this Travel Survey. Nat Grier said they would, and that the Travel Survey
       had been deliberately designed to have a little bit of overlap with the Park & Ride survey.



                                                           2 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



    9. Fernando de Aragón asked how much detail about park and ride will be included in the t-
       GEIS. George Alexiou said he would have a better idea after meeting with TCAT.
    10. Cathy Valentino said lack of affordable, convenient daycare is one of the biggest concerns
        she has heard from Cornell employees during the past 20 years. She pointed out that park and
        ride locations could be good locations for other conveniences such as daycare, dry cleaning,
        grocery shopping, etc. Bill Wendt said the university currently is engaged in the first phase of
        proposing expanded daycare opportunities on or near the campus. Jonathan Kanter said the
        Town is very interested in knowing the proposed location for a Cornell daycare facility.
    11. Herb Engman said he is still very concerned about affordable housing. He pointed out that
        Cornell owns most of the land close in that would be appropriate for housing development.
        He said the Town has met with as many of the decision makers at Cornell as they can think
        of, including President Skorton. Bill Wendt pointed out that a Mayor's Roundtable has been
        established to address the issue. Ed Marx said that in the next couple of months the County
        will be coming out with strategies about providing more affordable housing.
    12. Ed Marx said he is anxious to hear what the t-GEIS proposed mitigations will be. He noted
        that members of the Resource Committee would like to discuss proposed mitigations as they
        are being developed. Kathryn Wolf and Andrew Eastlick said the agenda for the February
        Resource Committee meeting will include presentation of the traffic and livability impact
        analysis and preliminary proposed mitigations. They said this presentation likely will
        continue at the March Resource Committee meeting.
    13. Ed Marx said he feels it will be particularly important to know t-GEIS proposed mitigations
        as the master plan is being developed. He said he is concerned that the t-GEIS may be falling
        behind the CMP. Bill Wendt and Kathryn Wolf assured Ed that the t-GEIS is not falling
        behind the CMP. They said the t-GEIS consultants met with the CMP consultants in
        December and were able to provide research and analysis results that were helpful to the
        CMP process. Bill said Mina Amundsen, the Cornell university planner, will serve as a
        liaison between the t-GEIS and the CMP on the Resource Committee.
    14. The next Resource Committee meeting will be February 22. The meeting adjourned at 3:00
        pm.

    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           3 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D




                             Page Intentionally
                                Left Blank
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                           Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #6
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                          Meeting Date: March 27, 2006
                                       Date Minutes Prepared: April 2, 2006
                                        Minutes Amended: April 5, 2006

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Bill Gray, Tim Logue
                        Cornell University: Bill Wendt, Shirley Egan
                        Department of Transportation: Bill Egloff
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nat Grier
                        TCAT: Dwight Mengel
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Cathy Valentino
                        Town of Lansing: Steve Farkas
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf


    1. The Resource Committee voted unanimously to accept the minutes from the 01/09/06
       meeting.
    2. Fernando de Aragón said public participation has been requested at Resource Committee
       meetings. He said the Committee is not legally obligated to make the meetings open to the
       public, but said he feels it would not be good to exclude the public from the meetings either.
       He cautioned that if Resource Committee meetings are open to the public they cannot become
       public hearings. Bill Gray said he feels that the Committee has been established to deal with
       technical issues, and public participation could weigh down discussions of those issues. Ed
       Marx said he feels that the public should be allowed to attend as observers only. Cathy
       Valentino suggested that the chair be allowed to recognize public attendees to speak briefly if
       they have important input. JoAnn Cornish pointed out that there are other forums for public
       comment on the t-GEIS. Steve Farkas suggested that members of the public be allowed to
       submit written comments to the Committee. Shirley Egan noted that written comments could
       be very lengthy and the Committee would be obligated to read them and respond to them.
         It was agreed that members of the public are allowed to attend Resource Committee meetings
         as observers and that the chair will use his judgment regarding allowing them to speak. Cathy
         Valentino said that if public attendance, but not comment, is allowed at Resource Committee
         meetings it will be very important for municipal representatives to "funnel" public comments
         back to the Committee.
    3. Annette Marchesseault provided an update on a web-based survey that Cornell is distributing
       to Cornell faculty, staff and students about transportation issues, particularly what would
       encourage more use of alternate modes of transportation. She said representatives from the
       various assemblies at Cornell have provided input, and the survey will be distributed to
       approximately 15,000 people, which includes all graduate students and a random sample of
       undergraduate students, faculty and staff. The survey will be distributed in mid-April. Dwight
       Mengel asked whether the survey will be assessing where people are coming from in order to
       gauge modal splits. Nat Grier said the survey will be asking respondents to provide direction




                                                           1 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         they are traveling from, distance they are traveling and what mode of transportation they are
         using.
    4. George Alexiou provided a review of roads selected for detailed corridor analysis. He noted
       that corridor analysis generally will stop one mile outside the Cornell hypothetical population
       growth area because studies have shown that traffic from a certain source generally becomes
       widely dispersed when it gets more than a mile from the source. George said corridor analysis
       will focus on road-related issues and adjacent land use, but there will be overlap between
       corridor analysis, intersection analysis and neighborhood analysis. He said intersections
       selected for analysis will be selected in part based on the corridors selected for analysis.
       Kathryn Wolf added that data will be collected for all three of these items within the next few
       weeks before school is out and people begin to leave for the summer.
    5. Committee discussed that "Cornell hypothetical population growth area," isn't an accurate
       term because the population growth will occur largely outside that area. It was agreed that
       the term "Cornell destination area" is more accurate. (This addition to the minutes was
       received from Susan Brock on 4/5/06.)
    6. Kathryn Wolf provided an update on neighborhood character and livability analysis. She said
       neighborhood analysis will be conducted along areas of approach corridors that go through
       residential neighborhoods, and some additional roads closer to campus that are not
       necessarily primary approach corridors but could experience an increase in traffic will be
       added for neighborhood character and livability analysis. She said the t-GEIS Working Group
       has initially selected roads to be added for neighborhood analysis and will confirm them with
       a group of representatives from the City and the Town. Workshops to collect information
       from neighborhoods will be conducted in May.
    7. George Alexiou presented the list of data that will be collected for approach corridor and
       neighborhood character and livability analysis. Bill Gray asked whether "building density" on
       the list is meant to indicate density of building of footprints or number of residents in
       buildings. George said both conditions will be taken into account. Herb Engman asked
       whether informal or "de facto" pedestrian crossings will be noted in the analysis. George said
       they will to the extent that they can be determined. Kathryn Wolf said the neighborhood
       workshops will be very helpful to determine this sort of information. Dwight Mengel
       suggested adding transit volume and capacity to the data collection list.
    8. George Alexiou and Nat Grier provided an update on intersections that will be selected for
       analysis. George reminded the Committee that the purpose of this study is not to do
       exhaustive intersection analysis, but to determine trends and areas where there may be
       problems due to hypothetical Cornell population growth, and that criteria was established in
       the scope to help determine which intersections should be analyzed. He said two intersections
       that were recommended during the scoping process failed to meet criterion a and 15 failed to
       meet criterion b.
         Ed Marx said he feels that the Sapsucker Woods/Brown Road/NYS Rt. 13 intersection should
         not be eliminated because it is very controversial. He also noted that the King Road/NYS Rt.
         96B intersection has a signal on the major corridor so should not be eliminated. Cathy
         Valentino said she does not feel that the Burns Road/NYS Rt. 79 intersection should be
         eliminated because it has a high accident rate, and could warrant more control measures.
         Jonathan Kanter said the Town still is collecting LOS data to provide to M/A/B, which could
         add some intersections back to the list. Tim Logue asked whether M/A/B will be moving
         outward in its analysis if it determines that there is a problem at an intersection near campus,
         in order to determine the source of the problem. George pointed out that traffic generally



                                                           2 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         starts to disperse by the time it is a mile away from the source. Cathy Valentino asked for a
         list of intersections that are being "dropped" according to the criteria.
         Bill Gray noted that the Committee discussion has been focusing on "things we know today"
         but the intention of the t-GEIS study is to get information that "we don't know." He
         cautioned that by focusing on some specific intersections such as Brown Road/NYS 13 the
         study could get to a size that is unmanageable. George said it is important to ask "What will
         we do with this data when we get it?"
         Ed Marx said the one-mile boundary seems "arbitrarily" drawn, and some very important
         intersections just outside the boundary have been missed. George asked whether Ed feels the
         one-mile boundary is irrelevant and should be dropped. Ed said no, but he feels it should be a
         little bit flexible. He recommended including intersections that are just outside the one-mile
         boundary to the north such as NYS 366/NYS 13, Triphammer Road/NYS 13 and Warren
         Road/NYS 13. He noted that future housing is likely to grow in these areas, since there is not
         much room for housing growth within the one-mile boundary. George said that analysis will
         be done by distributing effects of Cornell hypothetical population growth according to
         existing housing patterns, then modifying it according to what is known about anticipated
         future housing patterns.
         Susan Brock asked what will be included in the intersection analysis. Nat Grier said it will
         include information about left and right turns, seconds of delay, etc. He said intersection
         analysis is a "reality" check. Some corridors may be working just fine but some intersections
         may be near failing. George added that analysis for intersections along a corridor can be
         useful to help determine what (if any) improvements to make along a corridor. Susan noted
         that there will be some interest in whether LOS is going to decrease at some of the
         intersections beyond the one-mile boundary.
         Bill Gray reiterated that the purpose of the t-GEIS is to determine improvements that should
         be made in the future. The purpose is not to address specific existing problems. Nat Grier
         pointed out that it is important to keep the number of intersections to be analyzed
         manageable. Tim Logue said he could recommend eliminating a few redundant intersections
         in the City if King Road/NYS Rt. 96B, NYS Rt. 96/Hospital, Triphammer Road/NYS Rt. 13
         and NYS Rt. 13/NYS/Rt. 366 are added back.
    9. Kathryn Wolf provided an update on the schedule. She said a bike/pedestrian workshop
       tentatively has been scheduled for April 25 and the neighborhood workshops are scheduled
       for May 1 and 3.
    10. It was agreed that the next Resource Committee meeting will be on May 22.
    11. The Committee established 05/22/06 as the tentative date for the next meeting. The meeting
        adjourned at 3:00 p.m.

    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members
