transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix D




                             Page Intentionally
                                Left Blank
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                           Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #5
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                         Meeting Date: January 9, 2006
                                    Date Minutes Prepared: January 17, 2006

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Bill Gray, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort
                        Cornell University: Andrew Eastlick, Bill Wendt, Shirley Egan
                        Department of Transportation: Bill Egloff
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Susan Brock, Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Sue Ritter,
                            Nicole Tedesco, Cathy Valentino
                        Town of Lansing: Steve Farkas
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf

                        Also: Bruce Brittain, Doug Brittain

    1. The Resource Committee voted unanimously to accept the minutes from the 12/21/05
       meeting.
    2. Kathryn Wolf provided a summary of public comments received during the public scoping
       period. She said there were 16 comments provided ­ 11 oral and five written. She said the
       majority of those commenting indicated that they felt the draft Scope focused too much on
       vehicular traffic, and requested more emphasis on pedestrian and bicycle issues and on issues
       related to neighborhood "livability." She noted that Bruce and Doug Brittain submitted their
       own version of a revised draft scope during the 1/3/06 public scoping hearing, although they
       had orally presented most of the items in that document during the 12/6/05 public scoping
       hearing.
         Herb Engman said the "revised draft scope" Bruce and Doug Brittain submitted reflects the
         official position of the Forest Home Improvement Association and was signed by members of
         five other neighborhood associations, but that it not reflected in the Response Matrix, which
         should be corrected.
         Kathryn said the public comments made Cornell aware that it needed to better communicate
         its intention with regard to information that will be evaluated for neighborhoods.
    3. Kathryn Wolf provided an overview of Cornell's revisions to the draft Scope with regard to
       neighborhoods. She said new sections focusing on neighborhoods have been added which
       will identify the existing transportation systems and issues evaluated in previous sections on
       pedestrians, bicycles, transit and vehicular traffic, as they relate to neighborhoods. Where
       analysis indicates that an increase in traffic will significantly impact a neighborhood, more
       detailed "livability" issues will be examined for that neighborhood. She said this will not be
       an exhaustive inventory of "livability" issues because that is not necessary for this project.
    4. Bill Gray said he was concerned by the amount of detail being requested in the public
       comments at the 1/3/06 public scoping session. He pointed out that the t-GEIS is evaluating
       generic population growth on the Cornell campus and where growth may occur on campus



                                                           1 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                  Appendix D



         has not yet been determined. He said that level of detail is too specific for a broad, generic
         study such as this. Kathryn Wolf noted that many people are not accustomed to a generic
         environmental impact statement, so tend to make comments about issues they are familiar
         with.
    5. Herb Engman said that if mitigation strategies which may affect neighborhoods are going to
       be approved as part of this project, then neighborhood issues need to be evaluated now.
    6. Kathryn Wolf pointed out that individual capital projects will still go through site plan
       review, and if it is determined that transportation issues related to those projects have not
       been adequately addressed in the t-GEIS, then a separate environmental review will need to
       be conducted for those projects.
    7. Bill Gray again pointed out that this is a broad, generic study and it is not, for instance, a
       zoning study, by the end of which all details would be fixed.
    8. Susan Brock noted that the way Findings Statements on the t-GEIS are structured will
       determine whether an environmental review will be required for a future capital project.
    9. Susan Brock said she did not understand what was being proposed for the neighborhood
       sections in the revised draft Scope and the Response Matrix and recommended making the
       intention more clear. Kathryn Wolf said the intention is to look at impacts of hypothetical
       Cornell population growth on residential areas along major corridors providing access to the
       campus. George Alexiou pointed out that neighborhood "livability" issues already have been
       examined in other studies, such as the NESTS study, and that information will be referenced
       in the t-GEIS. Kathryn said more detailed analysis will be conducted for some residential
       areas identified as having significant impacts from hypothetical Cornell population growth.
       Fernando de Aragón said he had not picked up that nuance from the language in the revised
       draft Scope.
    10. George Alexiou pointed out that mitigation strategies will benefit all traffic, not just
        additional traffic.
    11. Ed Marx said it is important to make clear that impacts on neighborhoods are not just traffic-
        related. He pointed out that some mitigation strategies, such as more busses, could also have
        impacts on neighborhoods. George Alexiou said that examining projected impacts in specific
        areas may be too fine a level of detail for a broad study such as this. Bill Gray added that if
        impacts are studied for a hypothetical building location, for instance, but the building is never
        constructed in that location, then the level of detail of the impact analysis would be
        unnecessary. He recommended examining impacts in a more general manner ­ for instance
        general impacts associated with constructing sidewalks in residential areas. Ed said he was
        comfortable with that method.
    12. Thys Van Cort asked whether the hypothetical growth boundary in Figure 1 should be revised
        to reflect downtown since Cornell is moving office space downtown. Bill Wendt said one
        way to mitigate population growth on Cornell's central campus is to move offices and other
        facilities off campus, and each such project would require its own site plan review, therefore
        the boundary does not need to be adjusted. Jonathan Kanter said that if a mitigation strategy
        is to move office space off central campus, without identifying a specific location, then the
        evaluation of impacts should be general. However, if the mitigation strategy is to move office
        space to a specific location, such as downtown, then the evaluation of impacts should be more
        specific. Bill Wendt agreed with that. He said that there may be many good reasons for
        moving more Cornell employees downtown, even though such a move might require more
        traffic mitigation and adjustment to Cornell TDM programs. Bill Gray asked whether there



                                                           2 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                               Appendix D



         might be a method for providing "credits" exempting Cornell from some requirements if it
         institutes certain mitigations, such as dispersing jobs from central campus.
    13. Kathryn Wolf reviewed the methodology for engaging neighborhoods. She said the Ithaca
        Neighborhoods Council and the University Neighborhoods Council are existing umbrella
        groups that have been asked to sponsor meetings with regard to t-GEIS neighborhood issues.
        Cathy Valentino said this strategy makes a lot of sense. It does not exclude neighborhoods
        and it captures residents living in areas that do not have formal neighborhood associations.
    14. The Committee reviewed the revised draft Scope and the Response Matrix. George Alexiou
        said it never was Cornell's intention to just focus on just vehicular traffic. He said in Section
        3.1.4.1 corridors will be examined on several levels ­ neighborhood issues will be included in
        analysis of corridors close to the campus, whereas on corridors further out the analysis will be
        more focused on vehicular circulation. He said it is also important to ask what the intention
        was when certain intersections were added to the list of intersections to be studied. Were
        people concerned about the LOS of the intersection? Were they concerned about safety? He
        pointed out that if no one is willing to increase the carrying capacity of an intersection, then it
        is not realistic to study it and propose mitigation strategies for it.
         Fernando de Aragón said that during the NESTS study it was determined that there was not a
         lot of public opposition to individual intersection mitigations, such as adding a turning lane,
         but there was recognition that there are many "mature" neighborhoods in which a three- or
         four- or five-lane road would be strongly opposed. George asked whether the proposed traffic
         analysis is necessary. Andrew Eastlick pointed out that such analysis could be useful for
         deliberating bodies to make decisions, such as whether to widen a road or spend money to
         improve alternate modes of travel instead. George agreed and said that there are reasons to do
         traffic analysis with the goal of improving traffic flow.
         Thys Van Cort asked for a definition of traffic efficiency. Bill Gray said it means greater
         efficiency of traffic moving through the system, which could include less stop time, which
         increases efficiency and reduces pollution. Cathy Valentino noted that traffic efficiency is a
         measure of the length of time required to get from one point to another. Bill Egloff clarified
         that it is a measure of the reliability of the time it takes. Dan Kwasnowski pointed out that
         improved traffic efficiency could encourage people to drive more.
         Herb Engman said that intersection analysis in neighborhoods should include quality of life
         evaluation. He said improving traffic flow at certain intersections in neighborhoods may not
         be in the best interest of the neighborhood. Ed Marx and Thys Van Cort pointed out that, in
         general, stop-and-go traffic is not good for a neighborhood.
         Herb Engman recommended adding three percent (3%) per year and five percent (5%) per
         year hypothetical growth scenarios since location of proposed buildings on campus are not
         provided. He said that if Cornell is not willing to provide information about specific building
         proposals then it is not "acting in good faith" with this project. George said Cornell does not
         have specific approved building proposals to provide. Fernando noted that there are two sides
         to the issue: uncertainty with regard to funding makes specific building proposals tenuous,
         but not knowing specific building proposals makes impacts, such as those on neighborhoods,
         uncertain.
         Shirley Egan pointed out that there are building proposals in Cornell's current capital plan
         that have been accounted for under what will be considered existing conditions for the
         purposes of the t-GEIS. She said she felt Cornell was being more honest by examining
         population growth, rather than building square foot growth, since people are the generators of




                                                           3 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                               Appendix D



         traffic. Ed Marx pointed out that any building projects that are going to occur on the Cornell
         campus in the next five years should already be known.
         Thys said that the type of vehicle contributing to noise (a qualitative impact) should be
         accounted for.
         George noted that air pollution should be reduced if single occupancy vehicle trips are
         reduced. Thys added that hybrid busses and more efficient busses also would reduce air
         pollution.
         Herb asked whether the multiplier effect has been accounted for. George said it will be
         included in the background traffic analysis. Kathryn pointed out that the P.M.-peak, the
         worst-case scenario, is what is being analyzed. If mitigations are made to improve impacts
         during the P.M.-peak, those mitigations will be in place to benefit other travel times as well.
         Ed asked whether examining the proximity of housing to places of employment would be
         included in the scope. Shirley said that it already is included in Section 5.1.1. Ed noted that
         housing is not specifically mentioned.
    15. Bill Wendt said Cornell's current Capital Plan will be added to Section 3.1.1 Relationship to
        Other Current Long-Range Transportation Planning Efforts.
    16. The Committee established 1/23/06 as the tentative date for the next meeting. The meeting
        adjourned at 3:05 p.m.

    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           4 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                          Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #4
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                        Meeting Date: December 12, 2005
                                   Date Minutes Prepared: December 16, 2005

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort
                        Cornell University: Andrew Eastlick
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou
                        TCAT: Dwight Mengel, Joe Turcotte
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Ithaca: Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Sue Ritter, Nicole Tedesco,
                        Cathy Valentino
                        Town of Lansing: Steve Farkas
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf

    1. The Resource Committee voted unanimously to accept the minutes from the 11/07/05
       meeting.
    2. Nicole Tedesco presented an overview of the Town of Ithaca's Transportation Plan which
       currently is being written. She said the difference between the t-GEIS and the Town plan is
       that the t-GEIS will take a broad look at transportation issues and will include general
       recommendations, whereas the Town plan will have some specific recommendations,
       including a map of existing and proposed bike and pedestrian routes in the Town. She said
       alternates for inclusion in the Town plan should be completed by the end of this year and the
       recommendations section will be written next year. Jonathan Kanter added that goals of the
       Town plan include improving pedestrian systems in the Town, reducing reliance on single
       occupancy vehicles and providing more data on traffic volume, speed and accidents. George
       Alexiou asked whether neighborhood issues would be addressed. Nicole said that livability is
       an important focus of the Town plan and a section on traffic calming in neighborhoods will
       be included.
    3. Kathryn Wolf reported on public scoping for the t-GEIS Draft Scope, which occurred at the
       Town Planning Board meeting on 12/06/05. She said there were 11 speakers at the scoping
       session, written comments on the Draft Scope will be accepted by the Town until 12/16/05,
       and the Town Planning Board will hold a second public scoping session on 1/3/06.
         Kathryn recommended that discussion on including issues raised during the public scoping
         not occur until after all comments have been received on 1/3/06.
    4. The Resource Committee reviewed the Draft Scope section by section.
    5. Nicole Tedesco recommended adding a short description of what the t-GEIS will include in
       the Introduction/Background section, in conjunction with the section about what will not be
       included.
    6. Kathryn Wolf distributed an outline of how data will be collected and analyzed for bicycle
       and pedestrian sections of the t-GEIS. She said that a web-based survey might be used to
       determine what might encourage people to use alternate modes of transportation to access
       campus. Jonathan Kanter asked whether this sort of information already had been collected in
       the recently completed Cornell employee commuter survey. Andrew Eastlick and Fernando


                                                           1 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                Appendix D



         de Aragón said data from that survey might be useful to establish attitudes toward transit, but
         another survey may be necessary to collect the specific data needed related to bicyclists and
         pedestrians. Andrew noted that this might be limited to a student survey since employees
         were recently surveyed.
         Herb Engman asked how many Cornell employees without access to computers may have
         been missed in the web-based Cornell commuter survey. Andrew said that the survey was
         introduced in a postal mailing and arrangements were made to include people without access
         to computers.
         Fernando pointed out that there already are some very specific proposals with regard to
         pedestrian and bicycle circulation in reports conducted by his office, the Town, the City, etc.,
         and surveys may not be necessary for these issues in the t-GEIS. Andrew agreed that it will
         be important not to duplicate what already has been done, but Cornell already has a system in
         place to conduct web-based surveys of its students, faculty and staff, so it would be simple to
         collect information from this group of users. George Alexiou noted that some information
         also may be collected from stakeholders attending focus groups.
    7. Herb Engman asked how data will be collected about people who come to campus but are not
       regular commuters, such as visitors, people dropping off children at day care, people bringing
       animals to the vet hospital, etc. Kathryn Wolf and George Alexiou pointed out that the t-
       GEIS is focused primarily on regular commuters. George said a multiplier can be used to
       establish a ratio between regular commuters and "other" traffic. Fernando de Aragón noted
       that most of the generators of "other" traffic (eg., the Vet School, Plantations, Statler Hotel,
       the Orchards, day-care, etc.) are fairly spread out on campus.
         Jonathan Kanter asked whether Cornell has accurate data on visitors and "other" traffic.
         Andrew Eastlick said that it is difficult to measure accurately. He pointed out that a multiplier
         is used to address the issue in the City's U-1 zone. Thys Van Cort said that multiplier is not
         reliable and it may be reconsidered. It was agreed that a new section 3.1.4.6 will be added to
         the Draft Scope to address visitor and "other" traffic.
    8. Dwight Mengel said that the transit section of the Draft Scope should incorporate data with
       regard to an increase in bus ridership during the recent spike in gasoline prices. He noted that
       Cornell may be able to help synthesize that data. He said when gas prices were at their peak
       Cornell employee ridership increased by 64 percent, which sometimes was beyond TCAT's
       capacity.
         Andrew Eastlick asked whether the increase in ridership occurred only within Zone 1.
         Dwight said yes, the increase occurred in the Ithaca urban area. He said rural areas
         experienced a steady increase but it was not such a radical increase as in the urban area.
         The Committee agreed that pricing should be included in the TDM sections of the Draft
         Scope.
    9. Kathryn Wolf reviewed the proposed process for engaging nieghborhoods. It will be a three-
       step process. The first step will be to send out a questionnaire. The second step will be to hold
       neighborhood meetings for comments on proposals. The third step will be a facilitated
       meeting with representatives from all neighborhood groups jointly attending to discuss
       proposals and impacts. Solutions for some groups may have impacts on other groups.
    10. Ed Marx said that when a corridor reaches its capacity it becomes difficult to access the
        corridor from side roads, and he asked how that would be addressed in Section 3.1.4.1.
        George Alexiou said there are methods to determine LOS-type data for corridors. Kathryn
        Wolf pointed out that the goal is to increase TDM programs and decrease traffic on corridors.



                                                           2 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         Thys Van Cort pointed out that nearly all corridors leading to Cornell are residential
         neighborhoods and the phrase "environmental carrying capacity" might be most appropriate.
    11. Kathryn Wolf pointed out that several comments at public scoping focused on impacts to
        neighborhoods. Thys Van Cort cautioned that sometimes neighborhood groups will organize
        such that the information they provide might skew the data. Cathy Valentino asked how
        neighborhood boundaries will be identified. Kathryn said that people will be asked to list the
        neighborhood they feel they live in.
         Fernando de Aragón pointed out that a great deal of information about neighborhoods already
         has been collected in studies such as the NESTS study. Fernando said the three primary
         outcomes from the NESTS study are:
              ·    Problematic intersections
              ·    Key implementation projects
              ·    Policy recommendations
         Thys pointed out that the NESTS study did not include the City. He also noted that speed and
         traffic calming are important issues to address. He suggested developing general
         neighborhood traffic calming guidelines rather than going to individual neighborhoods to
         collect data.
         Ed Marx said that proposing neighborhood-specific mitigation measures has the possibility of
         creating a great deal of controversy. He noted that the residents along Coddington and
         Hanshaw Roads have strongly opposed construction of new sidewalks along those roads.
         Herb Engman pointed out that what works as mitigation in one neighborhood may not work
         in another neighborhood.
         George Alexiou pointed out that this study can only get into a conceptual-level of proposed
         mitigations for neighborhoods or the entire study will be bogged down just with
         neighborhood mitigation measures.
         Tim Logue recommended meeting individually with neighborhood groups to collect
         information about concerns, important issues, etc. He said information not applicable to the t-
         GEIS could be distributed to the applicable municipalities. He pointed out that the Town
         Planning Board could help determine which of the comments are or are not applicable to the
         t-GEIS. Nicole Tedesco noted that much of the information may be applicable to the Town
         Transportation Plan.
         The group agreed that a new Section 3.1.6 will be created in the Draft Scope to address
         Cornell-related transportation issues in neighborhoods.
    12. Thys Van Cort recommended adding background information leading to the City parking
        permit systems in Section 3.1.5.
    13. The Committee discussed the next meeting time, date and location. The next meeting will be
        on Monday, December 9, 2006, from 1:00 p.m. ­ 3:00 p.m. A downtown location is
        preferred. Jonathan Kanter will check the availability of the Town Planning conference room.
        (It later was confirmed that the next Resource Committee meeting will be in the Aurora
        Conference Room of the Town Planning Department.)
    14. Jonathan Kanter asked whether the Draft Scope should be revised and redistributed to the
        Town Planning Board prior to the 1/3/06 meeting. It was noted that issuing a new, revised
        Draft Scope could be confusing to the public. It was agreed that Cornell will make a short



                                                           3 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                              Appendix D



         presentation about proposed changes at the beginning of that meeting, but that the Draft
         Scope will not be modified until all public comments are received.
    15. The meeting was adjourned at 3:20 p.m.

    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members




                                                           4 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                              Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #3
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                        Meeting Date: November 7, 2005
                                   Date Minutes Prepared: November 14, 2005

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Bill Gray, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort
                        Cornell University: Andrew Eastlick, Bill Wendt
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou
                        NYSDOT: Bill Egloff
                        TCAT: Dwight Mengel, Joe Turcotte
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Ithaca: Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Sue Ritter, Nicole Tedesco
                        Town of Lansing: Steve Farkas
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf
                        Village of Cayuga Heights: Brent Cross

    1. The Resource Committee voted unanimously to accept the minutes from the 10/24/05
       meeting.
    2. George Alexiou presented the method that will be used to determine the background traffic
       growth rate. He said that the historic annual traffic growth rate in Tompkins County over the
       last 15 years has been 2.2 percent, which is in line with NYSDOT's assumption of a 2 percent
       annual traffic growth rate. Therefore, George concluded that a 2.2 percent annual traffic
       growth rate was a reasonable starting point. He said the next step was to subtract out
       Cornell's contribution to background traffic. Over the last 30 years Cornell's population has
       consistently comprised 30 percent of the County population and Cornell population growth
       has comprised one-third of the County's population growth in the same time period.
       Therefore a background traffic growth rate of between 70-75 percent, or 1.5 percent
       compounded annually, was established.
         Bill Gray asked whether the background traffic growth was assumed to be universally
         distributed. George said that is the case, but he pointed out that Cornell can be more precise
         in assessing traffic impacts from its future population growth by using geo-coding and other
         methods. Bill noted that a universal background traffic growth rate may not be adequate if
         there is significant growth in a concentrated area in the County. George pointed out that it is
         very difficult to project how the region is going to develop which will affect future
         background growth in specific corridors, and that it may be useful to work with planners in
         the County to try to determine trends.
         Fernando de Aragón pointed out that one disadvantage to the background traffic growth
         method being used is that it does not necessarily address travel corridors that are near or at
         capacity. George said that it was important to establish a reasonable and understandable
         background traffic growth rate, which is why the method he outlined is being used. Everyone
         agreed to the methodology.
         In response to a question about construction traffic, Bill Wendt said that the level of
         construction activity should remain about constant, and therefore it is covered by the
         background traffic. It was noted that this should be explained in the GEIS.



                                                           1 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                Appendix D



    3.    Andrew Eastlick presented the hypothetical population growth scenarios that Cornell will
         use in the t-GEIS. They are based on historic population growth on the campus. One scenario
         is based on 30-year historic population growth, which would yield a 0.5 percent per year
         increase in population, or approximately 1,500 persons, over the next 10 years. A second
         scenario is based on population growth from 1990-1999 which would yield a 0.1 percent per
         year population increase, or approximately 300 persons, over the next 10 years. The third
         scenario is based on population growth from 1980-1989, which would yield a 1.0 percent per
         year population increase, or approximately 3,000 persons, over the next 10 years.
         Fernando de Aragón said it might be helpful to break down the population figures even
         further to indicate, for instance, how many undergraduates live on campus. Andrew noted
         that Cornell currently has a recommended cap on undergraduate enrollment, so population
         growth primarily is anticipated among graduate students, staff and faculty. George Alexiou
         and Kathryn Wolf pointed out that Cornell can use geo-coding to determine where all
         commuters living off campus come from.
         Kathryn Wolf pointed out that the hypothetical population growth scenarios to be analyzed
         are for the main campus, within the boundary shown in Andrew's presentation. Thys Van
         Cort asked why the study boundary does not extend beyond the Town line into Dryden. Bill
         Wendt said that within the next 10 years most growth at Cornell is expected to occur on the
         main campus within the identified boundary. Jonathan Kanter pointed out that any substantial
         development at Cornell would take several years to be approved and could be addressed in
         the five-year update of the TIMS.
         Bill Gray recommended that the phrase "For This Study," be added to the title of the diagram
         outlining the area in which the hypothetical population growth will be studied.
         Ed Marx asked how construction traffic for Cornell projects is considered. Andrew Eastlick
         said that construction traffic would be considered in the background traffic. Bill Wendt
         pointed out that construction traffic generally does not occur during the standard a.m. or p.m.
         peak hours. Bill also noted that Cornell generally can only accommodate a certain amount of
         construction at any given time, so construction traffic figures generally are steady. Ed Marx
         said that it is important to make this clear.
         Jonathan Kanter noted that traffic impacts will occur outside the study boundary established
         for Cornell's population growth scenarios.
    4. The Resource Committee reviewed a preliminary list of potential intersections to be analyzed.
       George Alexiou presented proposed criteria to be used to determine which and how many
       intersections would be analyzed in detail. The first step would be to identify major approach
       corridors to campus such as state or county routes, then identify key intersections along those
       thoroughfares that lead to campus. Key intersections would be identified as those that have a
       four-way stop, are signalized on the major route, etc. The second step would be to identify the
       key intersections from step 1 that would be impacted by Cornell population growth. Detailed
       analysis would be conducted for intersections identified in step 2. George pointed out that
       intersections to be studied should be a reasonable distance from campus, such as one mile
       beyond the boundary established for the hypothetical population growth scenarios.
         Bill Gray asked whether it was assumed that all traffic would travel beyond the one-mile
         boundary. George said no, but it is reasonable to assume that traffic will have dispersed
         enough by the time it reaches the boundary to have minimal impact.
         George added that another component of the criteria would be that if Cornell population
         growth resulted in a certain percent increase in traffic at a certain intersection, a complete



                                                           2 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                               Appendix D



         analysis would be conducted for that intersection. He said this is a typical method used by
         many communities and it is common to use a 10-15 percent threshold in this method.
         Thys Van Cort said it seems that applying this criteria would eliminate many of the
         intersections from analysis. George estimated that it would yield about 30-35 intersections.
         Tim Logue expressed concern about using a percent threshold for volume of traffic. He said
         that percent change in delay also is an important consideration. George said it would be
         difficult to include delay in the criteria because it would essentially require that the analysis
         be conducted in order to determine whether the intersection warranted detailed analysis. Tim
         said he felt it was important to somehow measure change in delay. He noted that the City has
         LOS data available for many of the intersections.
         Thys Van Cort pointed out that many commuters from West Hill are headed to Cornell, but
         there are only a few intersections along the corridors, such as NYS Rt. 96. He said a 15
         percent increase in traffic volume on that corridor would be very detrimental. Ed Marx said
         that a 15 percent threshold really could be translated as a 30 percent increase in traffic
         volume because it would include 15 percent increase in Cornell traffic and 15 percent
         increase in background traffic.
         George said that many jurisdictions have certain threshold guidelines. Jonathan Kanter
         pointed out that there is not a blanket threshold in this area because of a great deal of
         variability. He suggested that a combination of percent volume threshold and LOS could be
         used on certain intersections. A 15 percent volume threshold may be fine for an intersection
         that has good level of service, but a lower threshold may be desirable for an intersection with
         a questionable LOS.
         George Alexiou said there should be some method for reducing the number of intersections to
         be analyzed from the 53 on the initial list. Tim Logue said he is concerned that using the
         criteria George outlined could eliminate analysis of some intersections that are already at a
         LOS level E. Ed Marx noted that close to campus most of the base traffic is Cornell-related,
         and perhaps a different criteria should be applied to intersections close to campus.
         Tim suggested that municipalities determine the LOS for intersections in their jurisdiction
         and that different percent volume thresholds be established for intersections operating at
         different LOS. As an instance, a 15 percent volume threshold might be acceptable for
         intersections operating at a LOS of A or B, but a five percent volume threshold might be
         more appropriate for intersections at LOS E or F.
         It was noted that the NYS Rt. 13 and Triphammer Road intersection should be added to the
         intersection list. Herb Engman also recommended that both one-lane bridges in Forest Home
         be added to the list, and Jonathan Kanter recommended adding the intersection at NYS Rt. 96
         at the hospital.
         Kathryn Wolf said that M/A/B will revise the intersection analysis criteria based on input
         from the Resource Committee. She noted that the intersection list will be presented at public
         scoping and some reasonable criteria is necessary to keep the list from becoming too
         unwieldy.
    5. The Resource Committee discussed the Draft Scope. Tim Logue asked if there is a way to
       provide more geographical data on housing. George asked if he meant housing un-related to
       Cornell. Tim said yes. George said that hosing projections would not be included in this
       study. Ed Marx said that the County is beginning to collect building permit data.
         Jonathan Kanter asked whether the Resource Committee is comfortable with the Draft Scope
         being presented to the Town Planning Board on 11/15. Fernando de Aragón asked if there



                                                           3 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         would be opportunity to make adjustments between the 11/15 Planning Board meeting and
         Public Scoping on 12/6. Jonathan said no. He said the document presented at the 11/15
         Planning Board meeting should be the same one addressed at Public Scoping, and revisions
         could be made following that. Kathryn Wolf pointed out that the Resource Committee
         reviewed the Draft Scope line-by-line at its 10/24 meeting, and the version presented at this
         meeting incorporates comments from that review.
         Bill Egloff suggested that Resource Committee members e-mail any comments to
         Trowbridge & Wolf. Herb Engman asked whether the list of potential intersections would be
         included in the Draft Scope. He said that not all Resource Committee members provided
         input on that list, and he did not feel that it was a Resource Committee list.
         Kathryn Wolf noted that the criteria for determining intersections to be analyzed would be
         included in the Draft Scope. Jonathan suggested including a preliminary list of intersections
         as well. It was agreed that the revised criteria would be distributed to Resource Committee
         members for feedback by the end of the week.
    6. Dwight Mengel asked whether a method would be established to look at transit systems.
       George Alexiou said there may not be a global methodology for examining transit systems,
       but specific analysis may be appropriate in certain areas. Ed Marx pointed out that a high
       number of Cornell employees ride the bus, so the bus system should be able to accommodate
       an increase in Cornell population. Jonathan Kanter recommended that a methodology for
       analyzing transit be included in the Draft Scope.
    7. Herb Engman asked whether bus and six-wheel vehicle traffic (particularly construction
       vehicles) would be analyzed in residential neighborhoods.
    8. Bill Gray pointed out that the information in the t-GEIS will be very useful for all of the
       municipalities in the County. It will be helpful in determining where to make future
       investments and likely will be helpful in finding solutions to many transportation problems.
    9. The meeting was adjourned at 3:15 p.m.

    Prepared by,
    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

    cc: Resource Committee members

transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                           Appendix D



                                           Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                          Resource Committee Meeting #2
                                                 Meeting Minutes

                                         Meeting Date: October 24, 2005
                                    Date Minutes Prepared: October 27, 2005

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort
                        Cornell University: Andrew Eastlick, Bill Wendt
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou, Nathaniel Grier
                        NYSDOT: Bill Egloff
                        TCAT: Joe Turcotte
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Dan Kwasnowski
                        Town of Ithaca: Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Sue Ritter, Nicole Tedesco
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf
                        Village of Cayuga Heights: Brent Cross

    1. The Resource Committee voted unanimously to accept the minutes from the 10/6/05 meeting.
    2. Kathryn Wolf distributed informational binders to members of the Committee and gave a
       brief review of the process being followed in developing the t-GEIS.
    3. Fernando de Aragón asked whether there were any general comments from members of the
       Committee. There were none.
    4. George Alexiou gave a presentation about the traffic analysis methodology that M/A/B is
       using, and methods being considered to determine background growth. Thys Van Cort asked
       for confirmation that the background growth in this project is only concerned with traffic.
       George said that is the case, but it is important to understand population growth as well.
       Fernando de Aragón asked whether state DOT data was included. George and Nathaniel
       Grier said it is included in Tompkins County data. Thys asked whether background data is
       measuring an increase in commuter trips or an increase in population or both. George said it
       includes both commuter trips and population growth.
         George said that the data collected and analyzed so far indicates that traffic in Tompkins
         County has been growing, on average, about 2.5% annually for the last eight years. Thys
         asked whether that growth rate is a combination of Cornell growth and other growth in the
         community. George confirmed that it is and he said that Cornell growth needs to be
         subtracted out to establish background growth. George pointed out that it is important to
         understand whether historic growth is a good indicator of future growth in the community.
         Thys asked where the population data was derived from. George said it is from the Census
         and Census projections. He said he is aware that Census projections are not always accurate.
         George said that population has grown in Tompkins County by approximately 1% between
         1970 and 2003, and that employment in the County has grown by approximately 2.4% since
         1980, while Cornell employment has grown by approximately 1% since 1980. Herb Engman
         noted that graphing total number of jobs at Cornell compared to the total number of other
         jobs in the County could be misleading since Cornell jobs represent a significant percentage
         of total jobs in the County. He suggested graphing jobs as percentages rather than total
         numbers. Nathaniel Grier noted that percentages could be misleading as well since a 1%



                                                           1 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         increase in jobs in Tompkins County is much more substantial than a 1% increase in jobs at
         Cornell.
         Thys asked whether data would be collected on the number of employees who live in
         Tompkins County versus employees who do not. Jonathan Kanter said that data is available
         in the 2000 Census. Nathaniel Grier pointed out that the objective in this project is to
         establish changes in traffic volume so it is not so important whether commuters live in the
         County or not. Brent Cross said that the recent northeast sewer expansion project may have
         useful, current data.
         Tim Logue said it may be useful to look at household growth, then study the distribution of
         growth throughout the County, to determine where there might be traffic problems. Thys said
         that housing prices have followed employment growth very closely since 1950 and if
         employment growth continues to increase as it has in the last five years it will result in
         unprecedented growth. He speculated that if housing prices continue to increase more
         employees will move out of the County and commute in.
         Thys asked Fernando if the 2.5% growth rate indicated by M/A/B seems reasonable.
         Fernando said it is consistent with national growth rates for traffic.
         George outlined methods being used by M/A/B to determine the impact area and the specific
         intersections that will be important to study in the t-GEIS. Herb Engman said that certain
         neighborhood groups, such as the Forest Home Neighborhood Improvement Association may
         be able to provide traffic data specific to their neighborhoods. Andrew Eastlick said that he
         received traffic data from the Forest Home group and provided it to M/A/B.
         Dan Kwasnowski asked whether type of job is relevant, particularly in relation to Cornell
         employees. Fernando said the Tompkins County/Cornell Employee Commuter Survey may
         yield some data about commuting habits relative to job type. George pointed out that traffic
         analysis for this project will focus on peak hour traffic. Thys and Herb said that there may be
         a relationship between salary and commuting time. Generally those with a higher salary can
         afford to live closer to campus and commute less. Fernando said there also may be data
         regarding this in the commuter survey.
    5. Kathryn Wolf reviewed the SEQR law and SEQR definition of a GEIS. She also reviewed the
       proposed schedule for the project. She said that a discussion of growth scenarios and a
       preliminary list of intersections to be studied will be on the agenda at the 11/7 Resource
       Committee meeting. The t-GEIS will be submitted for an informal review by the Town
       Planning Board at its 11/15 meeting.
    6. The Resource Committee reviewed the Draft Scope. Ed Marx said the introductory
       paragraphs are misleading. The first paragraph indicates that the t-GEIS is being written to
       study potential Cornell growth, but the second paragraph says the proposed action is Ten-year
       Impact Mitigation Strategies (TIMS). Kathryn Wolf said the wording may need to be revised,
       but she clarified that under SEQR law the action must be something that is approvable, which
       is why TIMS is the action. It will be the mitigation strategies that will be approved.
         George added that there will be a range of growth scenarios and a range of mitigations; not a
         single mitigation strategy for each growth scenario. Ed asked who will choose the mitigation
         measures. He said it would not be useful to develop the t-GEIS and then still have to go
         through the SEQR process for all Cornell projects anyway. Kathryn Wolf said that the intent
         is that the t-GEIS will address the transportation impacts of future Cornell projects, and
         provide a better understanding of the overall vision for development at Cornell.




                                                           2 of 3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         Brent Cross asked how the t-GEIS might affect private or municipal projects with regard to
         SEQR. George said it is not the intention to do SEQR for the mitigation projects themselves
         during this project. The intent of this project is to determine how the highest growth scenario
         at Cornell would affect the infrastructure and what might need to be done to mitigate that.
         Ed pointed out that building infrastructure is not an immediate process and that it would need
         to be in place in time to handle an increase in growth at Cornell. Bill Wendt said that is
         exactly why this project is being undertaken.
         Tim Logue asked for clarification that the t-GEIS is focusing only on home to work commute
         trips and not other commuter trips. Bill Wendt noted that it is assumed that if impacts of peak
         hour traffic have been mitigated, off-peak impacts also will have been mitigated.
         Ed and Thys pointed out that it may be necessary to isolate certain areas. Thys said that in
         certain areas on Friday afternoon and mid-day on Saturday traffic is just as heavy as typical
         weekday peak-hour traffic. Jonathan Kanter said it may be useful to identify some corridors
         to be studied in addition to individual intersections. Fernando pointed out that there are some
         very distinct corridors leading to Cornell.
         Herb asked whether traffic mitigation for special events at Cornell should be addressed. Bill
         Wendt pointed out that they already are very well mitigated. JoAnn Cornish agreed, and said
         it would be good to note that in the t-GEIS.
    7. Thys asked whether members of the Resource Committee would be expected to attend the
       Dec. 6 public scoping session. Bill Wendt said Committee members are invited to the public
       scoping but are not required to attend.
    8. The meeting was adjourned at 3:00 p.m.

    Annette R. Marchesseault
    Trowbridge & Wolf

                                          Transportation-Focused GEIS
                                      Resource Committee Kick-Off Meeting
                                                Meeting Minutes

                                         Meeting Date: October 6, 2005
                                    Date Minutes Prepared: October 10, 2005

    Attendees:          City of Ithaca: JoAnn Cornish, Bill Gray, Tim Logue, Thys Van Cort
                        Cornell University: Andrew Eastlick, Bill Wendt
                        ITCTC: Fernando de Aragón
                        Martin/Alexiou/Bryson: George Alexiou
                        NYSDOT: Bill Egloff
                        TCAT: Dwight Mengel
                        Tompkins County: Ed Marx
                        Town of Dryden: Steve Trumbull
                        Town of Ithaca: Herb Engman, Jonathan Kanter, Sue Ritter, Nicole Tedesco,
                        Cathy Valentino
                        Town of Lansing: Steve Farkas
                        Trowbridge & Wolf Landscape Architects: Annette Marchesseault, Kathryn
                        Wolf
                        Village of Cayuga Heights: Brent Cross


    1. Cathy Valentino and Bill Wendt welcomed members to the Committee and provided opening
       comments.
    2. All meeting attendees introduced themselves.
    3. The Committee established the schedule for meetings through the end of the year. The next
       meeting will be on October 24, a second meeting will be on November 7 and a third meeting
       will be on December 12. All meetings will begin at 1:00 p.m. and end at 2:30 p.m. in the
       TCAT Board Room.
    4. It was confirmed that Fernando de Aragón will serve as chair of the Committee.
    5. Kathryn Wolf and Andrew Eastlick provided a presentation outlining information about the
       project background, scope and schedule.
    6. Thys Van Cort said he still is unclear about the proposed SEQR Action and asked for further
       clarification. He asked whether the t-GEIS would, as an example, fulfill the SEQR
       requirements for certain future Cornell projects, such as a new parking lot. Kathryn Wolf said
       that the t-GEIS will not fulfill all SEQR requirements for future projects, although it is
       anticipated that the transportation impacts of future projects will have been studied
       generically in the t-GEIS, and that may fulfill most SEQR requirements for traffic-related
       aspects of the project. Specific transportation impacts not covered in the t-GEIS will have to
       be studied in the SEQR analysis for each individual project.
    7. Ed Marx asked whether the t-GEIS will include clear mitigations for incremental amounts of
       campus growth or population increase. George Alexiou said that there is likely to be a menu
       of options, rather than a single proposed mitigation.
    8. Bill Gray noted that the Resource Committee essentially is the MPO Planning Committee,
       but the Town of Ithaca has been proposed as the lead agency. He asked why the MPO was
       not proposed as the lead agency. Bill Wendt and Fernando de Aragón said that the MPO does



                                                           1 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



         not have legal standing in the SEQR process. Bill Wendt explained that Cornell and the Town
         previously had established a Town/Cornell Transportation Committee, which grew into the
         Town Transportation Committee. The Town now is drafting a Town Transportation Plan. He
         said that process made proposing the Town Planning Board as lead agency the next logical
         step for preparation of a Cornell t-GEIS. He and Cathy Valentino noted that the Resource
         Committee is a way to provide comprehensive coordinated review for all involved agencies.
    9. Bill Gray noted that the t-GEIS is likely to become the framework that other Cornell projects
       are "hung" on.
    10. Thys Van Cort noted that, in addition to the lead agency, involved agencies often make
        findings statements on the proposed action or plan during the SEQR process. He asked
        whether the City would be asked to make a findings statement on the t-GEIS when complete.
        Kathryn Wolf said that involved agencies will make a findings statement if/when they
        reference the t-GEIS, either on transportation-related impacts of a future Cornell project, or a
        transportation-related improvement in their own municipality. Jonathan Kanter said it is
        assumed that the Town Planning Board (the proposed lead agency) is the only agency that
        will formally approve the proposed action, Ten-year Impact Mitigation Strategies (TIMS).
        Other involved or interested agencies will have the opportunity to endorse TIMS.
    11. Thys Van Cort pointed out that there is some concern about the proposed lead agency, since
        the lead agency establishes and directs the process. He said his understanding is that involved
        agencies have a legal responsibility to either do findings on the proposed action, or to adopt
        the Town's findings on the proposed action. Jonathan Kanter clarified that involved agencies
        are not required to make findings until they reference the t-GEIS in a project review. He
        noted that some municipalities may never reference the t-GEIS.
    12. JoAnn Cornish noted that the Town Planning Board has only expressed its intent to be lead
        agency, but not all involved/interested agencies have yet concurred.
    13. Bill Wendt and George Alexiou said that the goal of this project is to have all
        involved/interested agencies feel comfortable with and agree with the final product.
    14. Brent Cross asked what happens if a municipality does not reference the t-GEIS in the future.
        Will they have fulfilled their responsibilities as an involved agency? Will they have
        culminated the process?
    15. Thys Van Cort said the process will end when the lead agency adopts its own findings on the
        t-GEIS. Then the involved/interested agencies can make findings on the t-GEIS immediately
        or later when they reference it when reviewing a proposed project.
    16. Herb Engman emphasized that all involved agencies must be clearly listed.
    17. Thys Van Cort asked for confirmation that the Town Planning Board has been proposed as
        lead agency because much of Cornell's future growth is anticipated in the Town. He noted
        that the City has four more days in which to decide whether to concur with the Town
        Planning Board as lead agency. Bill Wendt confirmed that much of Cornell's future growth is
        anticipated in the Town and he pointed out that most of Cornell's parking already exists in
        the Town.
    18. JoAnn Cornish questioned why the County was not proposed as lead agency. Ed Marx noted
        that it is possible that there will never be a Cornell project that falls under the County
        jurisdiction for review and approval.
    19. JoAnn Cornish asked whether SEQR is the right mechanism for this type of project. Bill
        Egloff of DOT pointed out that it is probably the only legal mechanism.



                                                           2 of 4
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix D



    20. Thys Van Cort and JoAnn Cornish asked why the proposed action is not referred to as a plan.
        Andrew Eastlick said that people who are not planners generally do not understand that a plan
        can be, and often is, a menu of options; not necessarily a single, prescribed plan. He said
        Cornell was concerned that referring to the proposed action as a plan would give the
        inaccurate perception that the final product would be a single prescribed course of action.
    21. Bill Egloff noted that the municipalities in Tompkins County are very fortunate that this
        process is occurring. He said it is rare in most other counties for municipalities to
        communicate and cooperate on issues such as transportation. He urged the group not to let the
        process unravel.
    22. Ed Marx said he thinks of the proposed action as a study of impacts of potential future
        Cornell growth and that mitigation strategies will grow out of that study. Bill Wendt, Cathy
        Valentino and Andrew Eastlick concurred with that understanding.
    23. George Alexiou presented some transportation-related studies and mitigation strategies that
        his firm Martin/Alexiou/Bryson has developed at other universities throughout the country.
    24. Fernando de Aragón suggested that geo-coding include City employees as well as Cornell
        employees, since they use the same roads. He said that data will be available in Phase II of
        the Park & Ride survey, which should be available in December.
    25. Ed Marx said the method used to analyze background growth will be very important, since
        Cornell is a big generator of background growth.
    26. George Alexiou said he will present different examples of methods to determine background
        growth at the next Resource Committee meeting.
    27. Jonathan Kanter asked about proposed Cornell growth scenarios to be studied in the t-GEIS.
        Kathryn Wolf said Cornell is still working on defining them.
    28. Kathryn Wolf said the next step in the process will be for Cornell to further develop the draft
        scope in preparation for public scoping. She said a draft of the draft scope will be mailed to
        members of the Resource Committee for their review prior to the next meeting. Resource
        Committee members will be asked to provide input on the draft scope at the next meeting.
    29. Brent Cross said he still is somewhat unclear about what the final product will be. He noted
        that many Resource Committee members are not quite sure where the process is going, but
        they are all going there together, which is an advantage.
    30. JoAnn Cornish said she anticipates that the draft Scope will help make things more clear
        about the process and the proposed action.

        the Resource Committee.
