                                             Appendix E
                           Background Traffic Growth Memo
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                              Appendix E




  Martin
  Alexiou                                                                            2414 Wycliff Road
  Bryson                                                                                       Suite 101
                                                                         Raleigh, North Carolina, 27607
Transportation Planning                                                             Phone: 919-881-1243
Traffic Engineering                                                                 Fax:   919-881-8081



MEMORANDUM
To:             Kathryn Wolf, Trowbridge & Wolf
From:           George Alexiou, PE
Date:           October 31, 2005
Subject:        Cornell University ­ Background Traffic Growth Recommendations

A meeting was held October 25, 2005 in Ithaca to discuss the method by which to establish
background growth for the t-GEIS. Attending the meeting were: Fernando de Aragón (ITCTC),
Ed Marx (Tompkins County Planning), Martha Armstrong (Tompkins County Area
Development), Jonathan Kanter (Town of Ithaca Planning), Mina Amundsen (Cornell
University), Andrew Eastlick (Cornell University), George Alexiou (M/A/B), Kathryn Wolf
(Trowbridge & Wolf) and Annette Marchesseault (Trowbridge & Wolf). This memorandum
reflects direction given to the consultants in large part through input from Fernando, Martha, Ed
and Jonathan as a result of that meeting.

Introduction

This memorandum provides recommendations for an annual background traffic growth rate to
be used for projecting future traffic on streets and intersections in the impact area defined for
the Transportation Focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS) being developed
for Cornell University. The rate is intended to estimate traffic growth that will be generated by
increases in non-Cornell population (including employment) over the next 10 years, and will be
applied to existing traffic count data. Traffic created by the various hypothetical growth
scenarios for Cornell for the next 10 years will be estimated separately, and added to the
background traffic to obtain the total future traffic at specific locations within the impact area.
These locations will be analyzed to determine the relative impact of potential Cornell growth on
traffic conditions.

Historic Traffic Growth

Historic traffic growth is recommended as the basis for projecting future background traffic
growth. At this point in time there is no clear understanding of or consensus on how much
population growth is expected in Tompkins County in the next 10 years. Previous population
projections are currently being updated and may be available around the end of the year.

Traffic counts on roads around the Cornell campus and major approach corridors to the campus
(generally within the Town and City of Ithaca) between 1989 and 2004 were analyzed to
develop a historic growth rate. As all parties have expressed greater confidence in count data
collected by the state, all but two of the locations analyzed were collected by the New York
State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT); these two locations filled geographic gaps on
the north and east approaches to the campus. A count was only used if it was clear that it was
collected at an identical location in different years. A total of 17 locations were identified.
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                Appendix E

Martin/Alexiou/Bryson, PLLC                                              Transportation Planners
                                                                               Traffic Engineers


Average annual growth rates for the above locations were calculated by a variety of methods
(total average, by periods within the 15 years, or by roadway volume). The average of these
methods resulted in an annual, compound growth rate of 2.2%.

It should be noted that this traffic growth rate exceeds the County population and employment
growth rates in the same period, reflecting a national trend of increasing per capita travel (i.e.,
the relationship between population and traffic growth is not linear).

This rate is also consistent with NYSDOT recommendations for projected traffic growth.
Statewide, when no other data is available, NYSDOT assumes a 2% per annum traffic growth
rate. Bill Egloff of NYSDOT also indicated that he felt that while some areas of Tompkins County
may have experienced traffic growth at 1% or less in the past several years, there are several
areas in the County which have experienced traffic growth in excess of 2% per year. When
estimating future growth rates for a specific area, they use the same methodology and type of
analysis as performed above for the roadway system around Cornell.

Therefore, a 2.2% per annum historic traffic growth rate is recommended as the starting point.
This includes all traffic growth over the last 15 years, and the next step is to determine the
contribution of Cornell University growth to this number. The remainder will be defined as the
background growth rate.

Background Traffic Growth Rate

There is no precise method for estimating Cornell's component of the historic traffic growth rate
of 2.2%. Various population and employment statistics were reviewed for this purpose, with the
following key findings:

·   Over the last three decades Cornell's population has consistently comprised just under 30%
    of the County's population.

·   In the same period, Cornell population growth has represented approximately 1/3rd of all the
    population growth in the County. This number has been in steady decline since the 1960's
    when Cornell's growth was approximately 60% of the total county growth to 20% of the total
    growth in the 1990's.

·   Cornell population growth has not always mirrored County growth. For example, between
    1990 and 2000 the County grew slightly while Cornell experienced no growth. However,
    traffic continued to grow in that period.

Therefore it seems reasonable to assume a background traffic growth rate of between 70 and
75% of the historic growth rate, or approximately 1.5% compound per annum.

Two points should be noted regarding this growth rate:

·   Cornell traffic can be expected to be more concentrated around the campus. Therefore, the
    background growth rate may be a little overstated for these locations. Since the traffic
    resulting from the hypothetical growth scenarios for Cornell will be totally accounted for as
    part of the analysis (and added to the background traffic), the overestimation of background
    growth will represent worst-case conditions.



                                                                                                      2
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                             Appendix E

Martin/Alexiou/Bryson, PLLC                                              Transportation Planners
                                                                               Traffic Engineers




·   There is a relationship between background traffic and Cornell employment growth. The
    Cornell Local Government Program estimates the multiplier effect of Cornell employment at
    0.36 jobs, i.e., every new Cornell employee generates an additional 0.36 jobs in the
    community. Higher Cornell employment growth implies higher background traffic growth.
    Therefore background traffic growth may be underestimated under the high Cornell growth
    scenarios.

Therefore on balance, a 1.5% background traffic growth rate is reasonable.




                                                                                                   3
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)




                                             Appendix F
                           Future Housing Distribution Memo
   transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                        Appendix F


                                       CORNELL UNIVERSITY
                                      Transportation-Focused GEIS

                                 Future Housing Growth Methodology

                                                July 13, 2006


Susan Brock's comments on the housing memo, July 10, 2006

I'll leave it to the planners to weigh in on the commuting population growth numbers assigned to each
corridor.

The memo doesn't support the conclusion that the current mode split should be maintained for the new
population. If the current ratio of parking permits to population won't increase, why "may" it be "implied"
that some of those living close to campus or within the TCAT service area will switch to an alternative
mode (thereby allowing the new people to grab parking permits in the same ratio as the current people)?
Most of those who live close-in are not new-growth people, since the new growth is occurring further out.
What mechanism will force those who are already here to give up their permits? Maybe mitigation
measures will induce some of them to switch from single occupancy vehicles to something else, but isn't
the purpose of this map to look at impacts from growth before mitigation measures are applied?

I don't know if your plans for this memo include posting it on the website, but if you plan to do that, you
should revise it to state undergrads aren't considered part of the commuting population and explain why.

Susan

M/A/B Response to Susan ­ July 13

Susan, as a transportation professional I am comfortable with the mode split assumption we are planning
to use. The main reason is that it does not change the potential traffic impacts on the neighborhoods
surrounding the campus which is one of biggest concerns and focus of this study.

As a reminder, the baseline assumption of the t-GEIS is that the existing mode split of the campus
population remains at current levels. This is because through a combination of existing TDM programs
and control of the parking supply, participation in alternative modes will be maintained at the current
ratio. This is considered the worst case scenario and more aggressive TDM and other mitigations could
potentially reduce further the number of drivers (the objective of the TIMS). Because of this assumption
that the same percentage of the new population drives as does currently, mathematically, if a higher
proportion of new drivers live farther out, then fewer will live closer in. Therefore, we would have to
reduce or even subtract vehicles from the inner roads and add them to the outer roads. The net effect on
the inner roads (i.e., the neighborhoods surrounding and near the campus) would be approximately the
same (at least on average) since the same traffic we moved to the outer areas will still pass through the
inner areas. The major change will be some more traffic on the outer roads, which we have dealt with by
making a worst-case assumption that all new traffic generated in each corridor originates at the outer edge
of the corridor, regardless of where the commuter may actually live in the corridor. In our model they all,
therefore, travel the full length of the corridor, whereas in reality it is a gradient.

It also should be noted that transit now serves parts of theses areas (albeit service is not as good as in the
Town of Ithaca and the City), and is likely to be expanded/improved even without Cornell growth, i.e.,
not as mitigation measure for this study. This will help the mode split.

I also wanted to note that the mode split is an average over the entire region. Therefore, trying to adjust it
(which would be tedious and imprecise anyway) would not substantially change the results.

Martin/Alexiou/Bryson, PLLC                       1
   transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                                      Appendix F




Mode split is only one of several assumptions we have to make. Where the new people may live is an
even less precise assumption. Other assumptions include which exact streets motorist use to reach campus
and the proportions using each route.

Susan, we are being diligent in selecting our methodologies and making assumptions. We know that
everything we do will be scrutinized and are going to great pains to ensure our work is defensible. Your
(and others) comments and questioning is welcome. Better now than later. The reality is that                 Deleted: (and the public would be
transportation planning consists of predicting human behavior under a set of future circumstances we can     surprised to hear this)

only guess at now. Those involved in transportation accept that. Of course in every transportation study
we could collect more data and do more analysis, but society cannot afford and would not agree to spend
the money needed to get exact answers. And because many of the factors that influence travel (and
housing) decisions are predictions about the future, the effort is not warranted.


Original memo
This memo outlines the methodology and assumptions regarding the distribution of future housing
locations of the Cornell community.

BASE DISTRIBUTION

The base distribution for the future housing growth is the existing condition. Addresses of commuting
faculty, staff and graduate students were obtained and geo-coded (the process by which a street address is
converted to a dot on a map representing that location). Only these populations were mapped since these
are the two groups that may grow under the hypothetical growth scenarios. Typically, the distribution of
the existing commuting population would be considered representative of the distribution of the
population growth anticipated in the hypothetical growth scenarios. As part of the traffic analysis,
Tompkins County (and beyond) was divided up into a number of approach corridors useful for estimating
the traffic impacts of the future growth. Each person for whom an address was obtained and successfully
geo-coded was mapped into the approach corridor containing their place of residence. The percentage of
total commuting population residing in each zone was calculated and shared with the Town, City and
County as the basis for estimating the location of future housing.

INITIAL FEEDBACK

The initial step in the future housing distribution was a joint meeting with local planners including
representatives from the Town of Ithaca, City of Ithaca, Tompkins County, Tompkins County Area
Development, and ITCTC. Each agency shared its knowledge of approved and late-planning stage
housing developments as well as information on long-term initiatives (public and private). General trends
include modest growth in the Downtown (and to a lesser degree Collegetown), with the most concentrated
growth occurring on West Hill and in the Village and Town of Lansing. Additional growth is anticipated
in the west and north parts of the county with more limited growth to the east and south. It was agreed
that these trends are generally reflective of the long-term socio-economic forecasts prepared for the
County and that they should shape future housing location estimates.

PROPOSED DISTRIBUTION

Based on this feedback, an estimate of the future housing locations of the Cornell employee and graduate
population was developed. Primary aspects of this distribution include:
   · Very little of the housing growth will occur within the City of Ithaca or the Village of Cayuga
        Heights. Notable exceptions include the Downtown core and Southwest Area.
   · Additional growth is expected toward the west (Town of Ithaca, Enfield) and northwest (Ulysses
        and Trumansburg). Because of the distance from Cornell and known congestion problems, this

Martin/Alexiou/Bryson, PLLC                     2
   transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                       Appendix F


        growth is not expected to represent as high a percentage of the Cornell population as for housing
        stock as a whole.
    ·   Significant growth is expected to the north in the Village and Town of Lansing. Much of the
        needed infrastructure is in place to accommodate higher densities than much of the county and
        the area is generally convenient to Cornell.
    ·   Areas to the east of campus (Varna, Danby, Dryden, Caroline and beyond) will continue to see
        strong growth because of their proximity and general ease of access to campus. These areas (as
        well as Enfield to the west) offer a rural or semi-rural experience, which is seen as a positive,
        lower prices and taxes than the City or Town and the option of being in the Ithaca school district
        (Trumansburg and Lansing are the other desirable school districts). The local shopping malls are
        not that far off from the area but still need to be reached by car. Also, some of these areas already
        have established communities of faculty and staff and graduate students.
    ·   The remainder of the county will see growth more or less proportional to the percentage of the
        Cornell population currently residing there.

The attached map shows the allocation of current driving commuters for each approach corridor, based on
the current housing distribution of those drivers who have a Cornell parking permit. Also shown is the
allocation of the future Cornell hypothetical growth for each approach corridor, based on where future
housing is expected to be built as discussed above. The latter allocation will be used for assigning trips
associated with the growth to the road system.

MODE SPLIT IMPLICATIONS

Because new housing will tend to be located farther from campus than the current housing distribution,
new Cornell persons will have less opportunity to use transit, bike, or walk. Therefore, the proportion of
new Cornell persons who have no choice but to drive could increase.

An explicit assumption of this study is that the ratio of parking permits to population will not increase.
The maximum parking scenario maintains the current ratio of permits to employees/graduate students.
Therefore, the proportion of people driving (or the drive-alone mode split) will not increase. This may
imply that a reduced proportion of those persons living closer to campus or within the TCAT service area
will be able to obtain a permit, and must switch to an alternative mode.

However, as the new driving commuters will likely live farther from the campus, they will travel longer
distances and use more of the road system that is being analyzed for the t-GEIS. This is accounted for in
the study in two ways. First, allocating more of the hypothetical growth farther out explicitly increases
the driving distances. Second, in assigning new trips to the road system, it has been assumed that all trips
generated in an approach corridor originate at the outer edge of the corridor, regardless of where the
commuter may actually live in the corridor, and therefore travel the whole length of the corridor.

It is therefore recommended that the current mode split be maintained for the new population.




Martin/Alexiou/Bryson, PLLC                      3

                                             Appendix G
                       Trip Generation and Distribution Data
                                (all trips tracked from origin to destination)
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                               Appendix G




    Estimating Vehicular Trip Distribution for Future Hypothetical Cornell Population

    The following diagrams in Appendix G show the new traffic attributed to hypothetical
    future Cornell population assumed along each roadway in the peak hour and, at
    intersections, how it splits or combines en route, for Scenarios 2, 3, and 4. Since Scenario 1
    is background traffic growth only (no new Cornell population growth) no estimates were
    provided for Scenario 1. In some instances, the numbers may not sum precisely because of
    rounding. Additionally, because vehicles were assumed to enter/leave the main roads into
    neighborhoods and residences some volumes may change between intersections. The
    following methodology was used to estimate the new traffic.

    A total number of new vehicle trips that could be attributed to future hypothetical Cornell
    population was estimated for Scenarios 2, 3, and 4. For each of these hypothetical growth
    scenarios these new vehicle trips were distributed to the approach corridors based on
    estimates of the residence locations of this population. Additionally, for each scenario, the
    distribution of parking on campus was estimated. The following figures summarize the
    process of connecting the trips from the home origins to the campus (and back again). For
    each scenario, the paths from a given approach corridor to a given destination or traffic
    analysis zone (TAZ) on campus were estimated using local knowledge and professional
    judgment supplemented with traffic count data where available. In some cases there might
    be one logical path between an origin and destination while for others there might be
    several. For every possible combination, these trips were tracked from origin to campus (or
    campus to home in the p.m.) and summed along all of the roadway corridors. For a
    complete description of the trip generation and distribution assumptions and methodology,
    refer to section 4.2.4.
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix G

                                              Appendix J
                                      City of Ithaca U-1 District
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)   Appendix J
transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                        Appendix J




      City of Ithaca Zoning Ordinance Section 325-20 G. (10)

      (10) Every year, by no later than April 15th, Cornell University shall submit to the Building
           Commissioner a parking report that shall include

                (a)       the annual parking inventory spreadsheet and summary;
                (b)       a count of full-time undergraduate and graduate students, full-time employees
                          and the full-time equivalents of each who are enrolled or working at Cornell; and
                (c)       a count of full-time undergraduate and graduate students, full-time employees
                          and the full-time equivalents of each who are enrolled or working at Cornell and
                          who are enrolled in the TDM Program.
    transportation-focused Generic Environmental Impact Statement (t-GEIS)                                            Appendix J
